reviewText:
https://youtu.be/thhUOb4WgXM
Skyshine's BEDLAM is a post-apocalyptic, turn-based combat strategy game with lots of RPG and roguelike elements that turn it into a really fantastic experience.

You command a giant, armored vehicle and try to survive on a nuclear wasteland, fighting mutants, cyborgs, marauders and powerful bosses. You are not controlling it directly though - you simply set a destination point on the map and hope to get there in one piece (yes, there are random encounters). When you reach it, there are several randomized 'quests' available. Quests usually feature a short gamebook-like fragments, where you decide how to act in certain situations and award you with something - be it meat and gasoline (which are consumed every time you go to another location or send a scout truck on quests), power cells (required to improve your mobile fortress and use special abilities during combat) or new kind of abilities.

In many cases quests also feature combat. Fighting system in BEDLAM is turn-based, but there is no order of movement among units - you can perform only two actions during your turn, but it's entirely up to you which characters you move or engage in combat. There are four classes of units and each of them has unique features and range of attack. Shotgunners (called trenchers here) have quite a lot of health points and can only attack nearby enemies, but their blast sends the victim one square behind its previous position. Snipers, on the other hand, are very powerful, but their health is low and they can only attack units that are far away. You need to experiment a lot and find the best tactics for each class. Winning an impossible battle with just one unit is not only possible, but extremely satisfying.

From time to time you get to fight bosses - very powerful creatures often accompanied by several of their servants. If you succeed in such battle, the boss will join you and you will be able to use him in combat like a normal unit - only it's far stronger and resistant! Perfect for end game challenges.

You can also use special abilities on the battlefield. If you are lucky and explore a lot, your vehicle will even be able to drop nuclear missiles on whole groups of enemies, or teleport your units wherever you want them. You can also use healing, become invisible for a while or confuse your enemies and make them attack each other. Using those skills requires a lot of power cells so you should collect them whenever it is possible.

Every time your unit kills enough bad guys, it gets promoted and becomes a veteran - it gets stronger and deals more damage, so it is a good idea to have them fight as often as possible. It's very risky though. Healing wounded units takes a lot of time and if they are killed - they are lost forever. You don't have many opportunities to get new party members, so you have to be extremely careful.

You are not able to load game if your fight doesn't go well - you have to accept the consequences of your choices. And if you lose all units that you have on board or run out of food/fuel - it's permadeath. Game has great replayability values. It takes around 1-1,5h to complete a scenario on normal. That doesn’t sound like much, but be aware that you WILL die a lot and will have to start from scratch, just like in roguelike titles, so you will spend many more hours before you see the good ending for the first time. BEDLAM gets REALLY hard in later stages and can kick your *** even at the beginning if you're unlucky.

If you like challenging, turn-based games with RPG elements - grabbing BEDLAM is one of the best decisions you can make.

PROS:
+ Combat - simple mechanics, lots of possibilities
+ Challenging like a rouge-like
+ Great replayability
+ Huge map
+ Unlockable races that alter the gameplay

CONS:
- No proper tutorial, only a couple of short videos
- Depleting reserves of gasoline/meat prevent you from exploring too much

TL;DR: If you like challenging, turn-based games with RPG elements - grabbing BEDLAM is one of the best decisions you can make.

reviewText:
Update:
I read the update about the new game mode that seems to adress my main issue with the game. Will play the game again as soon as I have some quality time and update my review. So please be advised that the text below is probably not a fair review of the current state of the game. It's a review for BEDLAM 1.0.

------------------
If you like tactical squad games where you get to play with your whole squad, be wary of this game. It has a weird mechanic where you get 2 action points per combat turn that can be used for any member of your squad for moving or shooting. This generally means that you will use one of your units for every shot (the strongest) and the rest of your squad will be relegated to being meat shields and dying or wasting actions for movement to stay out of harms way.

Sadly this makes the combat which is the most important aspect of the game very un-fun to me and since combat is the most important aspect of the game where you spend the most of your time, the whole game is just not worth it to play.

reviewText:
Prologue:

In SSB, you command a huge juggernaut machine, driving through deserts and rocky lands and sandstorms, in an attempt to leave your heavily damaged, constantly under attack colony and find a fabled Aztec City where you can live in peace. Will you manage? It's all up to you. IT might sound easy, but it is nowhere near as easy as you might think.

SSB is a mixture of the Banner Saga, FTL, Fallout and XCOM with a number of questionable design decisions. I want to make that clear right off the bat. It does a great job of making a post-apocalyptic FTL and and it does a poor job immitating XCOM.

So, now that we have this out of the way, let's see what the game does well and what poorly. Since my review is a tad outdated, I can tell you this: Version 2.0 made a good amount of changes and fixed a ton of bugs. This tilts my review slightly further towards recomending the game.

The GOOD:

1. Great AI. IMO, this is the point that outweighs all others. The AI will do its best to make your life a living hell, and that is something that needs to happen more and more in current games. I really enjoy when the AI actually exploits my mistakes and doesnt simply do a dumb move just to tickle my ego and make me feel like I'm so freaking smart, MLG PRO gamer. NO. The AI will punish you for your mistakes. This is really important to me, and I hope it is for you.
2. The artwork is very thematic and beautiful.
3. The music fits the post-apocalyptic theme perfectly.
4. Making hard decisions is both rewarding and satisfying.
5. Exploration is very rewarding and makes you feel good for picking all those exclamation marks.
6. Lots of locations to explore and lots of enemies to fight and allies to gain.
7. A really good battle system that resembles XCOM. I am pretty sure the devs will fix the stupid flanking (that presently doesnt even work) and will allow the player more flexibility, as it looks the only choice at this juncture.
8. A beautiful mixture of four of my favorite games, the Banner Saga, FTL, Fallout New Vegas and XCOM.
9. Winning a battle has never been more satisfying - especially against THIS TYPE OF AI.
10. Progression is rewarding - it makes you feel good and it makes you realize what you're fighting for.
11. Lots of unlockable weapons, variations and vehicles. Some are play-though based and some are not.
12. Great replayability. I know for a fact that I will be giving this game a lot of play-time, because I want to beat it and I am not discouraged by failures.
13. Great value for the money - the pre-release build was a few euros cheaper, but since I judge my games like 1 euro for 2 hours of play time, I am sure that in order to learn the game, get used to its quirks, learn how the AI works, and beat it will take me absolutely over 40 hours, so it falls into the good category of games in my book.
14. Lots of unit races, most of which you even get to play (as in units or heroes).
15. Punishing gameplay is not exactly a bad thing. Ironman games are not as bad as they seem. Life, in itself, is an Ironman game. There is no looking back, there is no save LIFE point, that you can go back to. You can't save LIFE at school and replay school if it turned badly. Or Save LIfe at college and replay it if you didn't do well...
16. The more you play the game, the better you get at it. Take the time to reel it in and learn from your mistakes. This type of gameplay always grabs me.
17. You need to think long an hard before making a move. Just like in chess, you need to consider every piece of the board and what kind of damage may it do to you.

And now, let's take a look at the bad. Don't be surprised if I repeat some of my good" points in this section. One man's boon is another man's curse...

1. Wicked learning curve. You will be spending hours and hours on end as you are getting used to how the units work - both yours and the enemy ones. It took me 2 hours to get past that barrier in order to let the game teach me what bosses do and how units react. And don't get me started on unit range

reviewText:
Updated as of  31 march 2016 upon the Redux variant:

I'll adress the concerns i had below in my old review before anything else. To note, most of these talk about the Campaign Mode, i'll discuss the Arcade after all this.

- Pacing : While the dozer efficiency upgrades are important, they become less so, so you can afford to use some dozer abilities more often and also cores are easier to find. This makes combat slightly more varied but not like you'll be able to fall back on these at least once a combat event. Due to having most of the points of interest shown on the map it helps to plan some things out now, and having to gather 4 relics does make it more interesting than just 'cross the area as fast as you can'. Same ofr the King Viscera end event which became slightly more varied. Either way, while it 'works' now, it feels like it was brute-force fix instead of a careful redesign.

- Events/lore/flavor text: Events/side missions are still things you mostly skip through. There is no gradient apart from do you want to risk it or not and the result is always random, and the actual content of the event matters little. I'll plug FTL again since it's relevant, but aside from having/getting some very rare random quest items, you can meet events you have nothing to do at with no options. .

- Combat: This is the big one. It's been mostly redone and rebalanced but it still very much feels like you're trading in people for enemies. It's better, since you're always tossing four people in instead of juggling resources/combat with fighting outnumbered, and each unit can move once/twice or once and shoot. The factional bonuses per number of rounds which now also affects you, and mostly works well within the context. The new UI interface which allows you to see enemy movement and attack is much appreciated, though it doesn't show if someone COULD attack you after moving if you're already in the square. Either way, the fact that each unit can now take a hit or two and the enemies are more 'boss-like' instead of fighting an atrition army of ants works for it.
Sadly... as i mentioned at start, after the first round it still very much feels like a cluster♥♥♥♥ and you're just trading damage for damage. Not as ridiculous as the previous installment but it's clear having all the people move, on the way the map was designed, you would end up with the mentioned cluster♥♥♥♥. You also end up in a classic Xcom scenario with the 4 people that if one dies, you can mostly end the run there. If two of your very high veterans die, you're done.  Raising up other people is risky as well, as due to the new 'bosslike' quality of the enemies you really need the extra damage each veteran level up adds.
PS: Defence now decreases damage as far as i saw, so that's something, versus the miss system.

- The difficulty: Is more tuned now, and you can play with a bit of free form enjoyment here and there instead of having it in your face every time.

- Arcade Mode: In the end, this is what you get when you boil the game down, and how the game i think should be played. A 5 minute by 5 minute jog, just punching through objectives and having some combat here and there. While working a lot better than the campaign and offering a more streamlined experience, it's far from the cool roguelike concept it started as.


In the end, i wish i could recommend it, but i still can't. The game is 'fixed' as much as you could without remaking core systems, but by not having the large problems it became even worse than broken, it became forgettable. Without the issues to distract, you get to see clearer how shallow it is.

Backed and wanted for it to succeed but minus some coffee-break 5 minute fun once in a while, it's not a sit-down game in the least, a game you could invest in for a good hour or two and get something out.

-----------------------
Updated a week or so after the initial fixes.

Played a few more hours, and all the below still stand. The 'double-back' fighting through King Viscera is ridiculously hard and showcases brilliantly all the horrible aspects of combat. No unit should be able to move and attack in the same turn or double-move, especially a boss character, and it's ridiculous to have two characters duking it out with equalizers for six consecutive rounds as the rest of the battlefield sits still.

Again i'd recommend against buying or overstaying your welcome in Bedlam thinking it'll get better with a few more hours under your belt.

-----------------------
Original review:

Cons:

- Poor pacing . There is no real brick-upon-brick feel with most encounters feeling haphazard at best and the random events feel either like giving you charity or blowing your head off. I'm sure a lot of people will say otherwise but i found also the fuel/meat dozer upgrades are a must have before anything else or you just run out of resources in the wasteland, that's even IF you win all your battles.

- Almost no actual choice. Combat aside, the game plays itself mostly, with almost no variance in event outcomes since aside from 'leave' you only have 'investigate the thing'. Stuff you pick up in your dozer or your crew composition rarely affecting the outcome, that's if you're lucky to pick them up in the right order of events. You can find the locked bunker now, and next turn you find the key, but you can't return to use the key on the bunker, even though you CAN go back.

- Combat feels unavoidably unforgiving and unbalanced. Following X-com style, your base recruits are horrible but unlike X-com, the number of people you have is very limited (16) for the entire campaign. Considering you often end up losing at least one, two people per battle at start, it takes its toll really fast. It also takes three kills for units to Veteran up, the first and only major unit upgrade, which sees their usefulness increased about 100% AND fully heal them in the middle of combat instead of waiting 20something days which at start can be a lot of downtime considering campaigns don't last too much into the 100 days to get to Aztec City, the goal. Thing is, it only takes a ♥♥♥♥ placement RNG at the start of the battle and you know you are just going to outright lose people no matter what you do. It wouldn't be bad if i also didn't have a huge issue with how the weapon ranges are used, and how the computer has a large advantage calculating all the odds, toeing the line of fire, making you waste a turn, versus a player that will have a hard time finding perfect positioning since there isn't even an option for a very visible, permanent-on grid to properly plan your moves. Banner Saga and Gorky 17 did this a lot better, Gorky 17 in particular. A final note, a large aspect is placed on Dozer weapons and Equalizers, but i found these too be way too expensive to use on a semi-regular basis, especially the Dozer weapon, which if you're lucky you'll shoot once, maybe twice a game.

- Event clicking and flavor text. Might seem like a small gripe, but what's the use in clicking through three or four screens of text, where you don't even have any interactivity apart from multiple chances of clicking 'leave'. Making me click more for an event five times to investigate doesn't make me read more, just skim faster and i even LIKE reading flavor text. Also at no point if i decided to go for it initially anyway will i just 'leave', and leave is such a cop-up design.

Pros:
- Great animation and world art
- Good concept and universe
- Decent music

Would i recommend it? No, go play FTL. Still the best roguelike survival system.

For the record: Played 1 easy which i won and four normals out of which i almost won one and one hard/bedlam which i noped out of so hard. The games are very short, which given the tablet-friendly interface i think was intended, but it does feel like by the time you reach the finish line you've barely finished putting on your racing shoes.

---

reviewText:
I haven't found Bedlam fun.  Which is a pity because it had huge potential.

The graphics are great and the animations are fluid.  The random encounters are exactly what I expected from a Rogue-lite style game.  Sometimes they're fair, sometimes they're not but that's just that way the dice rolls.

My complaint is with the tactical combat mechanics.  They're honestly stupid.  Each side gets two turns.  It doesn't matter if you've brought one unit or six.  You can move the one unit twice or two of the six units once.

Think about this for a moment.

Most of the units will be unable to move in any given round.  There is no numbers advantage; a small team tends to be superior as their members don't stand around like numbskulls whilst getting shot-up.  No team composition will give you an advantage until you start getting high health and high damage veteran and elite members.  That's not tactical play.

There are four classes of combatant scaling from high health and low damage melee fighters to low health high damage snipers.  A melee fighter can attack someone adjacent to them only - which makes sense.  However their low damage means that attacking with a melee fighter is a waste of a precious turn.  They're meat shields in the purest sense.

Ranged units can attack only at a very specific distance.  A sniper unit can attack someone seven paces away.  If the enemy is six or eight paces away they cannot be shot at all.  How does this make any sense?  Why doesn't damage or to-hit probabilty scale with distance?  A lot of the gameplay reduces to hoping an enemy will run into the narrow band of a ranged unit or trying to coax them into one with a sacrifice.

Nothing in the description, video or screenshots indicates that this is the tactical style.  That no real gameplay is shown is very telling and should have been a huge warning for me.

Still complaining about the tactical game.  Units are not placed at the start of battle they're dropped in randomly, a melee unit could start well behind a sniper unit who is too close to shoot the enemy.  Why - when I am instigating the attack - would I possibly want my units deployed like that.

Bedlam could have been a great FTL / XCom mix but as it stands it's a game of chess where your opponet randomly kicks over your pieces.  It's not fun at all.

reviewText:
I tried to enjoy the game, I really did. But after making it to aztec city and then being told you have to head back and do it all over again, the game very quickly became boring and uninteresting due to how hard it becomes to win, Like the difficulty becomes a vertical cliff face when you face King viscera.

The combat system is good in theory but executed terribly, a feel that you get from the whole game really, it could have been so much more, but it wasn't. I waited with baited breath to play this after the E3 trailers and reviews, and to be honest I feel let down. Yeah its not to bad considering its a budget $20 game but still...

There just isnt enough unlockable characters and machines and storyline to keep you wanting to trudge through the difficulty and keep playing. I thought this game was fantastic initially, but once you get to the whole king viscera part of the story you just want to ragequit, because it facerapes you hard. reviewText:
This is a great little game! Great atmosphere, music, style and very enjoyable. Many negative reviews are the early version of the game, which was unfairly hard. At the current state, it is NOT very challenging on normal difficulty, once you understand the mechanics, which are pretty simple. Here are few simple tips to get you going:
1.	Upgrade your dozer asap
2.	Don’t spend energy on equalizers, at least until/if you get some really good ones. In most cases it is better to use the default dozer weapon. Only use the weapon if there is no other option and you risk losing your lvled crew member (obviously, don't ever risk loosing your lvled chars)
3.	Sniper is the strongest char by far. By mid game my main sniper delivers 20-25dmg, which is enough to end even a boss fight.
4.	It is essential to level up your crew: give kills to the same crew member. Your main crew must be able to 1-shot your enemy to avoid taking damage: you will need 10dmg to kill any regular enemy. This is easiest with snipers, as they dish out 10dmg at lvl4.
5.	Once your main team is leveled up to 10+dmg, start leveling up some backups. To allow injured crew time to heal
6.	Position your team right on the edge your enemy’s firing range + their move range. This way the enemy can’t move and shoot at you in the same turn. Eventually they will decide to move into your firing range and you will reposition and 1-shot them
7.	If enemy BLITZ is inevitable – use the dozer weapon to get them drunk. This is a great opportunity to level up your crew and/or get pickups.
8.	Melee chars are also great, especially once you level them up to 10dmg. Since they have good health and range – you can easily get pickups and don’t worry too much about being hit. Also they are the best to avoid BLITZ (if you can’t use your dozer weapon) – because you can simply charge in and not die
9.	If you still have trouble with difficulty – check out game wiki and youtube

GLHF!

reviewText: Let me pre-face this with Skyshine's BEDLAM is a hard game. It is not easy, and it is made that way. It is punishing, brutal and difficult. It will chew you up and spit you out a thousand times over, and I like it for that. If you have read the reviews you will see a lot of complaints about the combat and that is what I would like to address for the most part in this review, becuase beyond that the game is entirely amazing.\n\nCOMBAT: Essentially BEDLAM is a game that takes a lot of inspirations from games like FTL, Banner Saga and XCOM. First and foremost, those who are comparing this combat to XCOM obviously haven't played Banner Saga, or they would see the clear translation to this game. Don't treat the combat in this like XCOM. If you do, you will die. The combat in BEDLAM needs to be treated more like a game of Chess. You need to find synergy between your units, and utilize them according to their strengths. For example, synergizing your trenchers and their knock back ability is essential for maintaining control of the map and positioning enemies where you want. Enemy just out of the range of your deadeye? Push him into range with a trencher and synergize your units. Play to your opponents weaknesses. Does your enemy have 3 deadeyes? Close the gap and play close. Get in their face and play smart so they can't make a play without getting punished. The combat is difficult and brutal, you WILL lose units, it is made this way for a reason. My only major complaint that I can't justify is the Blitz-o-meter. In my opinion the blitz function is what makes the combat over the top difficult. It basically takes the game from an 8/10 on the difficulty scale to a 9.5/10. If the enemy is going to get a blitz, I should too, or no one should get one at all. Also, unit placement. Having heard about this game from the FTL I was super excited to get my hands on it - in the trailer it  looked to like a combination of FTL (world) and fallout/xcom (battle).

I'm ~5 hours into the game at the time of writing and am having a blast. There are definitely things that can be improved upon, but given that the devs are a team of three and they are incredibly active with the community I'm not at all worried that we'll have a really polished game in the upcoming months.

When I started I was literally trading unit for unit with the enemy - after a few frustrating (but fun!) runs I was learning to position my troops, use my items effectively, and take out 10+ enemies without losing a single soldier.

Highly recommended if you enjoy turn based strategic combat.

reviewText:
This game is tough, super tough and on the surface may seem unfair but after spending more time with it and experimenting with my approach I've started getting the hang of it.

That being said you're going to wipe a few times, you're going to lose members every time, and you're probably going to rage quit some too. Despite all of that I've found myself enjoying the game. The combat is reminiscent of the Banner Saga, the random maps and resource management remind me of FTL, and the aesthetic a bit of Mad Max (but more cartoony).

Some tips for those starting out:
-Upgrading is important but those power cells are also needed for your Dozers weapons and equalizers and these can have a huge impact in helping you survive early game.
-Make good use of cover and line of sight, these are key.
-Despite what's been said melee fighters are not pointless, they never seem to miss and if you nurture them their damage beefs up and they can be great meat shields (but be ready to sacrifice them to claim some elites).

Admittedly, there may be some balancing to be done and they could definitely explain a bit more going in but all in all a fun game despite the learning curve.

reviewText:
So I just finished my first trek down to Aztec City and I have to say I had a really fun time with it. Like a road trip with your friends! Through a desert! Oh such antics you and your friends get up to along the way. Like watching Bill get eaten by an acid-spewing mutant, or selling Ted and his buddies off to a group of nomads for some fuel. You know, typical road trip shenanigans.

But seriously, Skyshine's Bedlam is pretty darn fun once you adjust yourself to the difficulty and figure out a few reliable strategies. My first run ended in a fit of desperation as I had a mere two units left from the rather large stock the game provides for you at the start and I just barely made it. I was saved by the simple fact that I had squirreled away enough resources to pelt enemies my dozer weapons and shield my two remaining veteran badasses as they tore through everything and everyone. Hugely satisfied when I finished my first run.

The combat is something I see a lot of mixed feelings on in the other reviews and I certainly see some of the concerns that people are bringing up. Often times in the early stages of the game it can feel like units just get chewed up before they can do very much and I think that's at least partially intended. If you could pimp out every single unit Bedlam would probably end up being far too easy to clear. As to whether or not it's fair...you can certainly move to minimize casualties through liberal use of the dozer's equalizer abilities (Shield!) and holding the squishier units back. I found that a veteran frontliner can be a rather useful shield/feeder for your rookie units. Regardless, I didn't find the game to be unfair most of the time.

One thing I do wish the game had was a way to get a lay of the land before each encounter, just to plan out which units to take. The random placement of said units took some getting used to but I don't mind it too much, a simple lay of the land would suffice.

There is also the willingness of the developers at Skyshine to keep tweaking/improving the game as demonstrated by their swift response to player feedback. That's probably the most comforting thing a new game could possibly have, attentive devs.

So, in sum the pros and cons!

Pros:
-Variety of Races/Dozers lends to replayability
-Unit ranking/leveling system
-Tons of different routes to take and dozens of events/points of interest to investigate (or run away from)
-Equalizer/Dozer Weapons add tactical depth
-Resource management creates a nice air of tension in both battles and travel
-Element of chance keeps things interesting
-Excellent Artwork/Animations

Cons:
-Difficulty curve is a bit rough for new players
-Two turn system can feel a bit restrictive
-Tons of exposition for the lore
-Tough to retain units and the ones that make it, may end up overpowered

Overall: Worth playing if you like strategy games, roguelikes, and/or trading innocent passengers for fuel!

reviewText:
-----------------------------
UPDATE 19/9
-----------------------------

So the devs just recently patched in some changes based on community feedback and I thought I'd give it a shot again - and it feels so much better! The initial difficulty curve has been smoothed out a bit (and having played a few runs prior made me more thoughtful before even clicking my first POI).

The game still retains its tough-as-nails difficulty, but now instead of a 0.1% fighting chance, it's bumped up to 1% and for a game like this, that is enough to turn it from frustrating to satisfying.

I now recommend this game but it's definitely not a game for everyone. You must really take the effort to invest in learning the game because its strength (the 2AP combat system) is also its weakness (if you don't get to know it properly).

If you are considering buying this game, I strongly urge you to check out some Let's Plays of other people doing runthroughs. But if you decide to get it, then welcome to Bedlam!

-----------------------------
ORIGINAL REVIEW
-----------------------------

The current iteration of Skyshine's Bedlam is not recommended for most people unless you live purely on the thrill of dying repeatedly due to factors outside of your control (and a very small segment of the gamer population does thrive on this!).

I'm REALLY trying to like this game because the art and concept is so amazing, but it's such a shame that the combat gameplay is a letdown.

I feel that the combat is too random such that your victories and losses have a lot less to do with your skill and more to do with your luck (namely initial unit placement or deployment phase, rookies dying too easily but not as easily replaceable). This game would often be compared to the new XCOM and FTL, but both managed to hit the mark on letting you feel you can usually triumph with skill.

This game would also be compared with chess, but whereby the latter has a consistent deployment layout and a strategy develops over time as you play, this doesn't happen in Bedlam as combat is too short to have a sense of chess' grand strategy, and the deployment issue has been mentioned earlier as well.

The good news is that this can be rectified by balancing the stats and lowering the initial difficulty curve so that rookies are slightly beefier and easier to level up, as well as letting melee units have some stopping power to delay enemy advancement into your squishy damage dealers.

Essentially, instead of feeling satisfied and enjoying that you one-upped against all odds of randomness when you win, you just feel disengaged with your units and just cross your fingers that they don't die each time. Outside of combat, the Dozer has no character and is simply a fancy looking stats-tracker (which is fine if the combat is improved).

If you look at the forums, the above issues are generally consistent with why people are unsatisfied with game, so hopefully the devs consider how to balance the hard roguelike intent against user enjoyment. I hope the devs are not discouraged by these feedback and see that a lot of us really want to enjoy the game, but certain aspects of it must be significantly improved to entice us to try it again.

I hope I can return to it later once some patches have gone through to help improve the above issues.

reviewText:
TLDR: Game is very good.  Think early stages FTL with a different setting and XCOM-esque combat.  It's getting a lot of bad reviews and that feels unfair, especially since they're already addressing the things that everyone is downvoting for.

Pros:
-Soldier classes and leveling: Would be nice to choose the stats to level, but it's plenty rewarding as is.

-Concept and setting:  It's basically post-apocalyptic FTL, what's not to love

-Replayability:  It's hard to unlock new dozers.  I mean like scouring the correct regions AND getting a little RNG love hard.  Similar to a few of the ships in FTL, where you have to get the right event in a specific race's region.  That said, I totally want to try the other dozers and this gives you subgoals aside from just beating the game.  There are also dozens of different weapons and boosts you can find in your travels, making each game a bit different.

-Combat: Combat is fun and gratifying.  A lot of reviewers seem to hate it, but if it was too easy to outsmart, then it would be dumb.  You'll likely have to sacrifice some soldiers to get levels on others, or to simply beat a battle.  Don't buy this game if the thought of playing god and having to sacrifice soldiers for the sake of your masterplan is an absolute deal-breaker for you.

Cons:

-Troop placement at the start of combat:  Honestly, this one isn't that bad.  Reviews keep saying you insta-lose snipers etc because they spawn nearest to the enemy.  While this does happen, you always get the first move.  So really, at worst you're losing a turn relocating your troops.  This is something they are updating anyway.

-Dozer upgrades:  Resource management in BEDLAM is pretty good.  Not overly complex, but managing fuel and food requires some forethought.  That said, there are dozer upgrades to reduce your food and fuel consumption that are pretty much completely necessary to survive.  You just end up leveling those to max before you can even consider your other options.

Last Thoughts:  If you really like FTL, even the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ RNG and the sometimes unfair boss fight, and $20 isn't going to make or break you, then pick this up.  It just released, it is good, and the cons listed here are already being worked on.

reviewText:
This game is brutal. No question about it. Make one wrong move and you can easily destroy every chance of getting to Aztec city. But it is possible. After 13 hours of playing, it's become completely addicting. It took me probably 10 hours of playing before I reached Aztec city on Normal Difficulty, and there's definitely a strategy involved. Once you find out that strategy though, it quickly becomes a well thought out game of chess, except with more blood.
The art is of course absolutely gorgeous as well, a gritty comic book style that is clear and easy to read. Just look at the images and video above.
Since the game is difficult and it took me a while to learn the strategy (have yet to master it though), I wanted to share a key staretgy that I learned while getting to Aztec city the first time: Use the Weapons with a rookie crew. The kills from them are counted towards getting to be veteran or leveling up. In later levels, I use a few veterans and always bring on a rookie, use the weapon right away, and with the nuker or the rocket one, level him or her up immediately. Hopefully that will put you on the right track.
Bedlam is all about strategy. The combat and managing resources. Once you learn the strategy, it's still difficult yes, but much more in grasp. This game is a unique blend of past favorites but with its own flair that truly sets it apart. Its hard to find games like this now. Skyshine has really got something special here.
Buy it now. :P

reviewText:
Developer: Skyshine Games
Publisher: Versus Evil
Release Date: 16 September, 2015

Before you’re reading anything let me tell you this: The game is hard
There’s a lot to be said about this game so this will be a rather long Review.
That means there’s a lot of those words that you actually have to read, Duh.
You have been warned.

Anyway let’s dive into Bedlam together shall we?

StoryYou’re the Mechanic, the last known Member of a once thriving guild of brilliant inventors and intrepid travelers. Sounds bad ♥♥♥ doesn’t it? But that’s not it!
You’re also in charge of a Crew, which will fight and ultimately die for you in Battles, while you have to manage your resources and upgrade the ever living ♥♥♥♥ out of your trusty Dozer, the Boneshaker, while navigating through the Wasteland that is Bedlam.

GameplayAs the Mechanic you take Control of your faithful Dozer, the Boneshaker (sweet name Pal), and a bunch of other People. You probably won't have company for long since Bedlam is a grim and dark place and most of your companions, be it goons that fight to the death for you or just some passengers, have a pretty big chance of ending up with a Bullet or Fist in their Face (head) or they decorate a Pike with one or more Limbs … or the Head. To make it short dead. Anyway don’t get too friendly with them. If you manage to be lovey dovey with one or some of your Companions they might end up turning into real Bad Asses also known as Veterans. After earning three kills your Pal turns into this shiney and white Veteran and gains a Damage or Health Point bonus. A Veteran can then level up again after snagging five Kills.
So your Dozer let’s talk about it.
In order to advance through Bedlam you need Crude and Meat. The first one is fuel for the Boneshaker and the other one for your Crew. I mean a Girl’s gotta eat. There are several ways to snag Fuel. The most common one is to kill Bad Guys on the Battlefield. If you manage to snag some of the Boxes you might end up with double Crude or Meat or even Power Cells.
The other one is by visiting POI, short for Point of Interest, and encountering random People that either give you some for free because they like your Face, look at you beautiful!, or they want to trade it for something.
Oh Power Cells? I nearly forgot those. Oh boy those are awesome!
You need those to upgrade your Dozer. There are four Rooms that you can upgrade and each of those Rooms can reach Level five.
One of those Rooms is responsible for healing your Crew and reduces the amount of days it takes. The other one decreases either the amount of Crude or Meat used per Day whereas the last one decreases the amount of Power Cells it takes for you to use Weapons or Equalizers (more about those later).

So the whole Veteran thing ... I guess you see where this is going?
Find Bad Guys -> Kill Bad Guys with the same Guy -> ? -> Profit.
Yeah that’s not a good idea. On paper it might be but in general it’s a terrible one.
I’ll explain shortly but let’s take about combat and your friends first. Heh friends ....
So anyway the game features a two action turn. That means that you have two actions per turn (Duh!). So what exactly does that mean? You can move and then shoot someone in the Face or do either of those twice. That’s it. The enemy can do the same so you’re on equal Grounds. Unless the Blitz Meter fills but let’s take about that later.

So let’s talk about your Crew for a while.
The game features four Classes.
The Frontliners are the Meat Shields of your Group. They have the highest Movement Range but the lowest Damage. In general you want to retrieve all those lil’ Boxes on the Battlefield with those Guys since it’s the easiest way to do it with them.
Next up are the Deadeyes. Yup you guessed it, those are filthy Snipers. Since Snipers are a bunch of cowardly Jackasses, they have to stay back so they, hopefully won’t get sniped (always makes me giggle when this actually happens). They have the highest Damage, of course, but the lowest Movement Range, not to mention they have a very specific attack range so you have to be in a good Spot to kill some People in their Faces.
And if you’re missing Shotguns here are the Trenchers. Those guys are the average Joes/Janes of Bedlam. They deal medium damage and have a medium Movement Range but in exchange for that their Attacks knock Enemies back. So make good use of’em Pal.
Last but not least are the crazy ones, the Gunslingers. Yeah those guys must’ve mistaken Bedlam with the Wild West since their acting like Pistoleros. They also feature medium Movement Range and Damage but whenever they take Damage from an Enemy in Range they get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and Shoot Back. Oh yeah that’s right you better kill them with one shot or they’ll just unload a Clip right into your Balls you filthy cowardly Mutant! Face.
You might even run into some odd special looking Fellas while cruising through Bedlam. If you manage to defeat those Posers they will join your Crew and Boy let me tell you … If you manage to do so the Battles will become so, oh so much easier! Not to mention those can level up as well. So take good care of those Buddy.

Remember me mentioning the Blitz Meter? Good, well let’s talk about the Meat of the Game for a while the Combat.
Combat in this game takes a lot of thinking. You can’t just rush in and one man show the whole Battlefield, unless you wanna end up Dead. So make use of that thing between your Shoulders.
You start of with random positions on the Battlefield. There are certain object you can take Cover behind and if you choose to do so you do gain one bonus: Being able to Dodge.
Unless you hide, glorious I must say, behind something you will always get hit. Always, there’s no way around it but the same goes for your Enemies.
Besides that you have to think twice whether or not you’re moving this character to kill this Idiot because it might be that you lose another one in the next Round due to him being too close to another unfriendly Unit.

Welcome to later! Time to talk about the fun stuff!
Weapons and Equalizers. Let’s be honest. There comes a time where you just go What the actual BEEP!?, because you find yourself outnumbered. There’s no way that you can win this Battle. Not a Chance. Unless you use some Weapons or Equalizers. You could either Nuke them down for example (always fun when Stuff just goes BOOM!) or you could heal Crew on the field. The choice is all yours but be advises that those all need Power Cells so it’s best to keep some at the back of your Dozer. Just for worst case Scenarios. I mean everything is a worst Case Scenarios but I mean real worst Case Scenarios.

VisualsWell it’s okay. I can’t say it’s bad nor good. I mean at the end of the day it does fit the game perfectly but I would have liked to see more Diversity. By that I mean if you’re on the Battlefield every Class looks exactly the same. Unless it’s a special Unit or a Veteran.
Besides that the game does look good. You always have the feeling that you’re ♥♥♥♥ed in a Wasteland full of Mutants, Rogue A.I, you name it.
The game does look really good but again … Just some diversity would have been dope.

SoundIt does fit the game. It’s not perfect and lacks here and there but overall it’s good. Though I have to admit that I do get a Borderlands Vibe, which I greatly enjoyed and consider one of my favorite Game Series, so I might be biased in that regard but the sounds overall are quite fitting. The explosions, Shots and Enemies are all fitting and keep you in the Wasteland.

What else can I say?Skyshine’s Bedlam is a good game. Yes it’s hard but People come on. It’s a Rogue-Like.

reviewText:
Good game - just don't expect X-Com style combat since while it looks similar the experience is pretty different. Since units have specific ranges they can shoot at (they get more options of shooting ranges as they level) it has something of a puzzle aspect to it.  Takes some patience to get to grips with it, but if you don't dismiss it for not being x-com style combat and persevere to learn the games nuances then it's rewarding.

Has quite a lot of FTL style random events (about 350 I believe currently) and it's important to visit the (!) points of interest to build yourself up rather than making a beeline for Aztec City. There is no real pressure to go directly there anyways aside from the difficulty rising as the days pass.

Art style and graphics have a nice look to them, and I like that veteran units get a different look to their armor. The sound and music compliment the game nicely too.

Overall a good game, that I feel is being a bit misunderstood. I can certainly see that the game could have unfair moments which would be frustrating, but I also feel that as you learn how to play it more it feels pretty rewarding to get farther than before. Judging by the dev posts currently on the forums too there are changes planned to make the easy mode (which is recommended for learning the game although unlocks aren't available there) more welcoming to new players, as currently it isn't really much different from normal outside a slower escalation of the difficulty level.

reviewText:
First of all, a bit of disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter, and as such, I do have a bit more connection to this game when compared to someone who just decided to buy it on Steam. Anyway.

THE PROS:

-The game is beautiful. You shouldn't just take my word for it on that, just look at the screenshots and trailer. Great art, great animations, great designs. All in all, high quality visuals.

-Nice UI. Thematically fits, and is non-intrusive. This is good.

-Great concept. The idea of travelling in a mobile fortress, trying to reach a utopia and save the people you have with you is awesome, and in this era of post-apocolyptic games everywhere, it's different enough to stand out.

-The writing. There's a lot of flavor text, for pretty much every event. The fact that even the most generic of this text is well written and very thematic speaks volumes about the care that went into this game.

-The events. This ties into the writing, but the events, for the most part, feel very fleshed out, and your decisions feel like they have meaning.

THE EHS:

reviewText:
This game has more personality than the last 5 I've tried put together.

The things I really like about this game are the brutality, the gritty decisions that must be made, and the hard-to-master strategic combat.  It draws all the things I loved about Banner Saga into a different setting;  you can attempt to make nothing but squeaky-clean decisions, but, very quickly find yourself having to make hard calls which will ultimately decide between making it to Aztec city or ending short in complete annihilation.

The combat is really addictive, and the ceiling of mastery is surprisingly high.  I love the replayability if I fail, and I love the replayability if I succeed (keeping unlocked dozers).  If you like turned based strategy, regardless of setting (and they really nailed apocalyptic wastelands) I'd say it's a must buy.  There's a really great blend of surprises and consequences-from-tacticle-decisions that keeps me going dozer run after dozer run.  It's brutal, and I think that's why I like it so much.

This is not FTL. And it doesn't have to be. This is not Banner Saga. And it doesn't have to be. This is not Mad Max. And it doesn't have to be. And it's also not XCOM.

Do I recommend this game: Yes.
Should you buy it right now (23.9.15): Not yet.

A bit of learning curve in combat with the game being too hard at first, (then when you understand the combat) too easy in the middle and depending on your power cell account either too easy or too hard in the end. At the moment it's about surviving in the beginning, using elites in the middle and trashing final bosses with the help of abilities (weapons and equalizers) in the end.

The game has a solid base and it is enjoyable at the moment, although in a bit masochistic way.

For a better experience this game needs some balancing, better UI in combat (for making it less strenuous counting the tiles) and fixing the game stalling bug in the end.

If you happen to try it anyway, just remind yourself that this isn't XCom and you're playing defence, not offense. Don't be overwhelmed by the difference in troop count, since both sides only get 2 actions per turn. That's also why you're usually better off with a small team (I use 3 or 4 in the beginning and always 3 once I get my first elite).

Pros
- Tactical combat
- Distinctively different(ly annoying) opposite factions
- Art

Depends
- Game is hard and unforgiving
- Combat is not like in XCom (I thought it was, had to get over this before I could enjoy it)

Cons
- UI could be better (calculating placement in combat is a drag)
- Combat is a bit too much about luck/elites/weapons/abilities (especially in the end)
- Has crashed a few times (5/13h) + game ended with a stall
- Text events offer no real choices

reviewText:
The font is supremely readable. The fact that I'm calling that the absolute best thing about this game says more about most strategy games than this particular strategy game so I'll review the thing properly too.

Bedlam is Banner Saga (engine and all) meets Mad Max meets roguelike. It's a largely randomized game where your goal is to get from the top of the screen (a city called Bysantine) aaaaall the way to the bottom of the screen (Aztec City) in a Dozer... which is a tank. Sure it might sound like a bulldozer but I assure you it is not. You must upgrade your Dozer with power cells, feed refugees with MEAT, and keep your fuel gauge as full as possible with CRUDE. You've also got soldiers who fit neatly within four classes: Deadeyes (squishy snipers,) Frontliners (tanks with bonesaws and riot shields,) Gunslingers (adaptable mid-range damage dealers) and Trenchers (close-range shotgun specialists.) These soldiers are renamable and have unique backstories that you will not read because they will die very quickly. Oh yeah, this game is HARD! It IS a roguelike after all.

During battles, which are faster paced than most in the genre, you and the enemy can move twice per turn. Not per character ala Banner Saga, per turn. Everyone is randomly placed too so you'd better move your squishies to cover so they'll get a 50% dodge chance. Along with cover, there are also MEAT, CRUDE, POWER, and explosive boxes littered around the map. Pick up some of those and you'll get more supplies (which you will need.) If you've got the power and the enemies are tearing you up, your dozer can fire off huge weapons or bestow helpful boons to your party. As you need that power to upgrade your dozer, though, you'll want to think carefully about deploying it. Soldiers can die in Bedlam. It's a roguelike after all. Guess what, though? There are elites! They suck! They can murderlate the holy hell out of your team but if you beat 'em, they (and their mighty abilities) join you... because MAD MAX, amirite?

All in all, Bedlam is a brutally difficult game that is also rewarding for anyone who, like me, enjoys brutally difficult games. It has twists and turns that I sure ain't spoiling here and like I said in the beginning, the text is infinitely readable... so YAY for accessibility.

Oh yeah, it's not accessible for newbies yet. There are tutorials and they do their job very well but the game is blisteringly hard, even on easy. The devs have said they might fix that. Here's hoping. No game should be painwalled after all. Inclusiveness for newbs and pros alike, right?

So that's my review. I recommend the hell out of this game.

reviewText:
Warning - This is not really a rougelike but it does possess some of that genre's elements. I would say its a tactical combat game with some light rpg and roguelike elements and....

UPDATE 3/31 - Version 3.450860234??? something like that...is out! The developers spent a ton of time rebooting the game and changing the mechanics from the two guys move per turn setup to the more standard XCOM style of move each of your guys then end turn. You can still play in the original mode via the options menu if you so choose.

The update also brought in a number of tweaks and additional content as well as a slightly altered path to victory that makes the game seem a little less grindy.

Overall all of the changes have been on the positive side and I stand by my original review with maybe a half point bump.

If there is one thing left to complain about (there are several but I'm just picking one) I wish there were some unique mechanics or skills behind certain elites passed the basic units of each faction. For the most part the units within each class all do the same thing more or less and it gets pretty bland after awhile. I've finished the game twice now and I am not sure if I'll be revisiting the wasteland anytime soon but I've def got my money's worth out of this title.

Kudos to the Dev for not jumping ship when the initial run of poor reviews came sliding in btw.

OG REVIEW:

Your ability to get enjoyment of this game will start and end with the combat. Since the combat style/mechanic is different than any other tactical style game I can think of you really need to spend a few minutes at least watching a let's play" and go from there.

Personally I enjoyed the combat style a great deal and it helped me to get over a number of blemishes I found along my journey through Bedlam.

Pros -

Solid Tactical Combat Puzzlesque Fights
Unique (as far as I know anyway) mechanics
Colorful artwork helps bring the bleakness of the game world to life
Unlockable dozers for future runs

Ac/Dc -
Extreme Challenge at Times (more on this later)
Violent
VERY Grindy

Cons -
Repetitive Gameplay - There are some choices to be made that can affect your journey via text choices but 90 percent of this game is going to be on that combat map.

To elaborate...

-Units and their abilities are very much interchangable same stats for all units within a class (only 4 of those) regardless of whether you start the game with them or pick them up along the way
there are Elite Units that contradict this with boosts in HP and damage but slower overall progression
Lack of individual skills makes many of the fights nearly if not exactly the same. If you do not mind grinding a bit this might not be as much of an issue.

-Replayability is Low
-The method of unlocking the Dozers are completely random

BALANCE - The begining of the game - Brutal
After a few runs - You realize that your gonna lose some people early on for most of
You can and should shrug these losses off.
Middle - Long and gets pretty easy once you have the hang of it.
End - Pretty tough again unless you spent about 8 hours or so grinding to get there.

So I would give this game a 5/10 but would recommend it if your a fan of tactical turnbased games and want to try something different. The combat mechanic is pretty intersting and takes awhile to get use to. Once you do your going to see a surge in success rate.

I hear there are still plans for substantial improvements to the games content and have some fixes in the works to restore balance. I would say this game probably should have be considered an Early Access Title until they come get through a couple more updates. There's potential for a much bigger game with more depth that could show up here in the next few months.

In the meantime its not a bad tactical combat game....its just not really a rougelike."

reviewText:
Fans of Judge Dredd / 200AD, turn-based strategy games / tabletop games, and anything with a wasteland/apocalyptic setting will feel right at home here :)

This is quite a challenging game. It's of that genre, and you will die! Not every run will be successfull, and sometimes RNG will cause your veteren sniper to be killed in 1 hit  (delicious permadeath) - with no possible way of you avoiding it. Yup, these things will happen, so if you are fine with that and enjoy games of a simular nature (X-com being a good example), then this game could be for you.

The actual gameplay comes in two halves. The first involves navigating the worl map and essentially plotting the course for your 'Dozer', choosing which path to take and where to stop and explore. Travelling the waste will use resources, which you can restock during your travels. These resources (meat, crude and energy) can also be used to upgrade and enhance your Dozer / units throughout your journey.

The other half of the game is combat. It's turn based, and uses a 2AP/moves per turn system. It's worth noting that unlike X-com where you can controll/move your entire squad each turn, this game just allows the use of those two action points. So after selecting a unit, moving it, and then ordering it to fire. Your turn will end and the enemy will then do the same. Those 2 action points may be spent however you wish (moving the same unit twice, ordering a unit to fire twice, making one guy move and another fire, etc). As a result of this you really do have to study the battlefield and consider your movements before doing anything, acting too hastly can have serious consequences (did I mention delicious permadeath?).

This game is much like FTL, but it's hard to say it's a clone. You are in a barren land, going from adventure to adventure and meet FTL like instances. Except the battles are turn-based instead of real time. And they're decent.

CONs:

* Upgrades don't mean much. They don't get you excited.
* Writing isn't nearly as good as FTL advanced edition.
* Instances are not as exciting.

reviewText:
I am recommending Bedlam for one reason, really, and that is that it's a fun, challenging game that will serve you hot death from the RNG gods more often than not. It's a game that will ♥♥♥♥ you off, and for a lot of people, after a few rage quits they'll be done with it.

However, should you stick around, you'll find that it's not actually a tactics/strategy game. I mean, it is in a sense, but the combat is almost a puzzle game. While random unit placement can put you in awful situations, with planning and proper management of your resources, you can overcome huge odds. In fact, I'd say Bedlam's strong suit is in how it makes you feel like it's impossible, but as you play and learn the mechanics, you start to really improve. Bedlam will drag you through it's brutal world with style, visceral brutality and a ton of character.

Skyshine is currently looking at ways to make the game a bit more accessible, so if you're on the fence because of other reviews, give the game a 'Follow' and see how things pan out. And while the 'FTL meets Mad Max' thing is not wholly far off, it's also not very accurate. Bedlam obviously owes a bit to both entities, but truly it's its own beast. I'm having a lot of fun with it, but I also enjoy the trial and error aspect of learing the ins and outs, and I absolutely adore the setting. If I had to give it a score, it would be a solid 7, if not an 8. It's a good game for those who are willing to try something new but at the same time familiar. While it's no FTL, it's a strong showing for Skyshine and I will gladly support any future endeavors by the team, especially if one was a full blown RPG set in the Bedlam universe (hint/hint).

reviewText:
This game is a solid tactical roguelike with interesting combat that's great for quick and fun play sessions.

The art and presentation is superb. I expected not to like the art, but it grew on me right away. It's closer to Borderlands than Fallout in tone, and that's not a bad thing.

The game is fast-pased enough that taking early loses is not overly punishing. And you will take loses, in your first fight. The combat is well balanced, but does not work like XCom or Fire Emblem, and if you try to play it like those games, you will certainly lose. It's closer to Chess, you will lose units, often in a single hit, but that does not mean you fail the battle. You don't have a ton of units to spare, but a single veteran unit can often carry an entire fight on her own, so once you start leveling up, the game gets more forgiving. Though losing a veteran is incredibly tragic, which, honestly, is why we play games like this right?

Overall the combat feels more like a puzzle than other tactical games. Because units will die so quickly, figuring out what units counter each other is very important to succeeding, and a large part of the fun.

The overmap portion is not incredibly deep, but still more fleshed out that something like FTL, and is beautifully rendered. Resources are rare enough that it's worth taking risks to gather more, but I didn't feel like I was running on empty the whole time. You start out with a good deal of breathing room, but bad choices and lost battles will quickly erode your supply.

If you like the look and setting of the game, enjoy interesting and new tactical challenges, and don't mind learning by losing a few battles or a few games, Bedlam is worth picking up.

If you were looking for XCom with a Fallout skin, this is not that game.

reviewText:
Another update 18/09

So after putting some more hours into it, I have a gripe that stems directly from the combat system. The longer you roam the wasteland, the more notoriety you have which is reflected by levels of threat (low -> guarded -> eleveted -> severe -> bedlam), akin in theory to the FTLs chase system, where it discouraged 'farming' or basically taking too much time. However, in practic, the threat level of bedlam does not coexist with its combat system, through which threat is represented. For each threshold you surpass, the battles are supposed to get tougher by simply putting more enemies on the battlefield. You face the same type of enemy units throughout the game, so they have the same health and damage throughout your whole journey. What is broken here, is that late in the game you encounter the same weak (as compared to your badass elite units) henchmen, but there are just way more of them, however, the numbers advantage they seemingly posses is mitigated by the two moves per turn system. Therefore, out of 15 enemies, only two, or even one move towards to attack you - easy pickings for your hardened lot. The rest is just grouped in the corner waiting their turn to enter the meat grinder.
The only battle headache is the random placement system, which can really put in a tough predicament right from the start. Still, you always go first in battle so you can immediately activate shields, damage absorbers or flat-out nuke clustered enemies.
In essence, you just drive around wasteland, hoping to unlock a new dozer (I didn't unlock anything yet), and scoring levels (= more damage output). And boy, you'll need your elites levelled if you are to have any chances with boss. What does it mean? If you manage to survive your first 20 minutes, you're rolling and the game gets grindy fast. Still, the potential is there, the game just needs tweaking.

Update 17/09

So I kind of finished the game on normal.

Let me say this. There are two difficulty bumps after which the game is a breeze (at least on normal). You hit the first bump right after the start - you only have rookies, who, for the most part, won't withstand more than one shot. Keeping them alive and leveling them is the tricky part. Some of them will die, but their sacrifice allows you to keep a force of capable veterans. Then, you gonna find the first elite recruitable. After the moderately hard battle, he/she joins. Elites are powerful units - they have more health, and their damage output raises each time they level. By the end of the game, one of my elites dished out 16 damage per shot (which means one-shotting regular and elite enemies, the only exception being the boss). I'd say that's pretty deadly.
The second difficulty bumps comes right after you established a foothold with your now veteran troops. The resources. All of a sudden, your fuel and food are almost depleted. If you manage to gather some, you good. But that's random, as most of it comes from points of intrests that hide a random encounter. It could be your precious fuel, or a band of cyborgs.
After that, you just steamroll. More elites join you, they level, you gather more powerful equipment for your dozer to use in battle (like a nuke, or a shield granting immunity to damage and regenerates your health each time someone hits you for one turn), etc. Most of the time I fielded my 3 elites and they mopped the floor with like 15 enemies without taking a scratch.

As for the random encounters, I'd like to see more crew-specific, contextual interactions. There were only a handful during my 3 hour playthrough, and I'd would greatly enhance the feeling of accomplishment and connection to your crewmembers if they had more options to interact during encounters. As it stands now, half of the encounters don't even give you any option to pick - just a quick, flavor text and that's it. Hell, I don't mind losing my guys because of a choice I made in a random encounter!

Everything written below still applies.

Also, I cannot comprehend how you can compare this game to Xcom (the new one).

---- Original review ----

I cannot recommend Bedlam in its current, underdeveloped state, as it lacks certain, IMO, fundamental features.

I do not share many reviewers' concerns about overall unbalance of the combat mechanics. I think two moves in a turn spent on whatever by whoever is an interesting concept. It just requires getting used to. However, I do have an issue with how uninteresting and not varied the characters are mechanically-wise. I.E. You start with 4 snipers, each of whom has the exact same stats. Like carbon copies. Same for your 4 gunslingers (each has 5 health, 3 damage, 3-4 range, 4 move). A wasted opportunity right from the start, a little mix up in the roster would greatly improve the decision-making process. Said gunslingers should all bee a wee bit different. Like imagine, one gunslinger with 4 health and 3 range, but 3-5 damage. Another one with 5 health, 2-4 damage, 2-4 range, and 3 move. You know, some tactical flavor.

Once a character levels up (after scoring three kills), their combat usefullness increases dramatically, and their stats go up in a fixed manner, which means we do not get to allocate any skill points. A real shame - the way it was in Banner Saga kept things interesting - there you could specialize classes, having direct control of how and what function a given unit would perform on the battlefield. What a wasted opportunity! For instance, I would heavily invest in health for my sniper given the chance, granting him survivability, but at the cost of lower damage output. I would increase the range and quickness of my shotgun unit, making them glass cannons, etc. Choices is what we need, to further adjust the characters to our playstyle.

Unfortunately, there are no active/passive skills either (sniper is the most 'exciting' class, as they have a passive chance for a headshot each shot), so there is no incetive to use your lesser units, as they are prone to dying extremely fast and cannot really dish out any proper damage. If the vanilla troops had a skill, like for instance your tank having a charge, or granade to use once per battle, that would justify using them in certain situations, even if they do not scale to the enemy stats-wise. Currently what happens is you end up using your two moves on your badassest guy, and reasonably so! A skill-tree, like choose one skill out of two per level - that's what Bedlam needs.

Same goes for equipment. It's all bound to a character and is unchangable. Your frontliners will use a simple melee weapon, always dealing 2 damage. After the level up, the damage will increase, but it's always a fixed value. You cannot influence it in any way, your troops gonna deal the exact same amout of damage each time they attack. Instead of a boring 3 damage each shot, why not introduce a 2-4 mechanics? What about finding weapons as you travel along the wasteland? We don't need an abundance of them - just a few to spice it up.

Apart from combat and character progression, the Dozer's upgrade system seems to be lacking. There are four areas of research - bio research (slower food consumption), armory (less power cells spent for using dozer's special equipment), barracks (faster soldier recovery), and engineering (less fuel used). By spending power cells, you can improve each, up to a level 5. Each level grants a % improvement in efficiency. And that's it. It could have been a small research tree for each research area, with at least a few passive bonuses to choose from, maybe an active bonus here and there. As it stands now, it just feels underdeveloped.

Nevertheless, the art, the feel, the world, the atmosphere, it's all here, and it creates a fantastic coherent entity.

In essence, the potential of Bedlam is huge, it may even surpass FTL, but as it stands, I cannot recommended it, even though I wish I could.

reviewText:
Skyshine's BEDLAM REDUX is a FANTASTIC GAME, It took some time for it to get there, but now  I'm happy to say that the Dev's pulled off something truly amazing with this game. They listened to everyone's concerns and complaints, and made a game that We all can enjoy! This game is about choice, not just in the story, but also in the game options you have. If you just want to have a quick go, you can tweak the settings to give yourself a smooth ride with some interesting challenges along the way. If you want to dig deep with more of a hardcore challenge, you can tweak the game to that level too, and for you indecisive players, there is a middle ground for you as well. I'm very happy with my purchase, the Devs need to be applauded and supported for the great job they did in making this a game for everyone and not just one group of gamers.

This is a turn based strategy rouge like game with an 80s cartoon feel and look to it. Replay value is through the roof! because of the randomized events, so every play through is different from the other. You can give your crew what ever name you want (their back stories and portraits remain the same though) to make your experience more personal and unique  to you. If you love casual or hardcore strategy this is the game for you. Oh and one other thing, if you see a guy out in the bad lands named Thandorr, do what I do, RUN!!!!!!.....

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9RBMyIu6YzY

For my full written review, and to leave me a comment, visit MouseNJoypad at; http://mousenjoypad.com/reviews/pc/skyshines-bedlam-review/

When I first saw Skyshine’s Bedlam at this year’s E3, I got to talk to John Mueller, Art Director on the project. Sitting down with the game, he told me of his team’s love of post-apocalyptic tales of survival, and their drive to bring it to the public. The idea originally started as a modified game of D&D, heavily inspired by properties like Judge Dredd, Dune, and Heavy Metal. As he showed me the basics of his game, I became lost in the world of Bedlam, as he spun me the tale of how this universe came to be.

Sadly, despite how well the world was painted for me at the event, Skyshine starts the game cold, with no introduction or even what the need to travel across the titular lands might be. I understand some won’t care, but the lack of an intro movie or narrative was a travesty, considering how absolutely amazing the world is once you get absorbed into it. This sad oversight, I wanted to treat like a band-aid and get it over with; because the rest of this review is going to be more positive.

Bedlam is like putting Mad Max, X-Com and The Oregon Trail together in a blender, and seeing what shakes out. Gameplay follows your giant technological wagon as you travel across the hostile wastelands of a world covered in sand. Players get no restore points, no redos- if you die, you go back to the beginning, Rogue. You’ll start the game choosing your race and dozer (your transport), and then you roll out of your factory, ready to cross the map like a barbaric Indiana Jones. I should mention however, my review copy only allowed me to play as Humans.

As you push on down the road, you may check out one of the points of interest on the map. It’ll consume some time, gas and food, but you may find something really important that you’ll need later on. For example, I went to one and found a small cave; and upon entering found a bizarre creature’s home. They gave me a Gremcatcher; something resembling a stone dream catcher, and possibly just as useful. Everything you find may seem useless, but you’ll discover uses for them… most of them… I think.

These story-based moments are delivered via short descriptions, but still manages to paint a vivid image of the pile of twisted metal blocking the road you’ve been traveling down, and the shriek of the mutants who have trapped you. While I would’ve loved to see more artwork in these sections, I’ll forgive it due to the large variety of traps and missions that have been placed in the game. This leads to constant mental debates, questioning if you really have the manpower to try and save a random group of survivors from some hostile Rouge A.I.. Sometimes, you’ll be rewarded- and sometimes you’ll test if fortune truly favors the brave.

But, no matter how well you play- eventually you’re going to get caught in a firefight, and it’s a joy to play them out. Battles play out like Advanced Wars, where you move troops around the board, seeking cover and utilizing squad tactics in order to keep your guys alive. Each character has their own strike patterns, power level and dexterity, and the more you bring onto the field, the less of a resource bonus you’ll end the battle with. This provides a real incentive to challenge yourself before every battle, as you try to think about how confident you are with two powerful characters over six disposable ones. You also have to worry about healing times, where injured soldiers must recuperate between battles. This keeps you from cranking out a ton of “trenchers” (shotgunners), and just huddling up in battle.

Each turn, you’re only able to complete two actions, be it moving one of your soldiers or taking a shot. This too adds to the desire to try to minimize your troops, otherwise you may end up with soldiers who stand there the whole battle, clueless. There’s also a challenge to delay that final death blow, because there are resources lying all around the map, giving you additional resources after the match. This is a job for the weak Frontliners (Shield and baton soldiers), as they’re able to run around faster than the other classes, and take a ton of damage. Each battle encourages you think strategically, and rewards you precious supplies for taking difficult risks.

Despite the difficulty, the game strives to be a journey through an unforgiving wasteland, and it succeeds. As I dug deeper into the game, discovering more about the lore of Bedlam, I found myself enamored with the game. It’s a difficult one, that offers very little forgiveness, and when you do fail, you usually have yourself to blame. This would be a great introduction to gamers unfamiliar with tactical role playing games, and a fun experience for veterans.

At first I was hesitant due to the mixed reviews; but after reading some of the negative reviews (most of them are so old, I ignored them) and after reading about the REDUX update, I figured why not?!?

To sum up: Love it! So worth the money. I had and am still having fun trying to kick the King's butt and unlock more Dozers!

I must say, It was hard for me at first; but, after a few games I got used to the battle mechanics and started kicking some serious Bedlam butt!

Cons:
The writing. Some events have too many clicks with too much reading. And don't like all the abbreviated-faction-specific talking - hard to understand.
What are the passengers for, just score?

Pros:
Great art, sounds and music
Love nuking the enemies
Sistamatic on Strugglebus is awesome!
Love getting the characters (Elites especially)
I could sorta control (still investing how I do this) the level of battle difficulty via the threat meter
The game gave me a chance in the beginning and I noticed the difficulty swing later (in Arcade mode, at least)
So far lots of replay ability for me; still seeing new events and I haven't even played campaign mode yet!

So if you are on the fence, give this game a go! Just as one of their options is: 'GO BEDLAM!' (that is hard mode, tho), And as active as this team is - you really can't go wrong! I hope they release more updates with more content, keep it coming Skyshine!!

The Redux patch brings Skyshine's Bedlam from the world's most confusing game of doubles tennis into the realm of an actual strategy game. While many people may have liked the two actions per side each round design, it seems far more flocked forth to give Skyshine's Bedlam a bad review.

Personally I held off on writing a review, because the Early Access portion of the title's existence was a week that existed only in an effort to avoid offending those Kickstarter backers who had paid extra to get the title early. I get the feeling that they may have had financial need to release the game when they did, and so I wanted to give them time to straighten the game out.

From what I have seen so far the Redux patch has made what was always a gorgeous strategy game into something a little more similar to games that have come before. No longer do you have to sit and watch the enemy take a step toward your highest level character, and then instantly kill them in one shot over the course of their turn".
