reviewText:
I wanted to write this review because I was on the fence with regards to whether or not I should buy it due to the mixed reviews. The most recent reviews tended to be positive and it was on a 75% sale. I launched it yesterday for the first time and couldnt be more pleasantly surprised. From the user reviews I read, I got the impression its been vastly improved (I can't pass judgement) but that there were still flaws (weird battle mechanics, repackaged downgrade from FTL (which I loved)).

So if you had the same sentiment or hesitation, then I'd suggest giving it a go. There are similarities to FTL, you jump from point to point, it makes sense to try and travel as much as possible so that you have the best possible chance at the final stages. You have different 'ships' which are unlocked after different runs. That's pretty much where the similarities end. The combat is totally different and I really enjoy it. You have 2 action points per turn for the whole squad (of up to 4 people) giving it a twist on the standard xcom, warhammer etc. every unit has action points mechanic.

Without spoilers:

Pros:
-Really hard and feels rewarding, I jumped into it blind and still dont have a preferred set-up (im looking at you xcom squad sight and snipers).
- Different resource management, food, fuel, power cores and people. The first 3 which are mainly gained during combat which is brilliant because they are on the battlefield, so if you dont pick it up and slaughter everything, you've lost resources. This makes for some interesting choices, should i let this squad member die in order to get all the resources on the map (there are some tough calls)
- Great art style, music and overall feel.
- Mad max type theme which I also enjoy (I know thats FOTM for most games right now, but still :))

Neutral:
- I played about 6 hours straight and finished one run (I think I had 7 attempts), so each individual run is fairly long and that can be especially rage inducing when you make a mistake one stop away from the final boss. However, also makes it that much more rewarding.

Cons:
- Still feels a little unfinished.
- There are typos and I've run into one or two bugs and one CTD
- Lack of content while exploring. For this to make sense, I'll compare to FTL, even after dozens of runs, you found new quests, new dialogue options became available depending on your crew. After about an hour in Bedlam, I started seeing the same events over and over and over again, which only have 1 outcome with 100% chance depending on the choice you pick.

Real Conclusion: I'm writing this review because I think the overall (mostly mixed) steam user reviews are not representative. The developers really shot themselves in the foot because all of the negative reviews upon initial release. Again I cannot compare, but perhaps that provides an opportunity to give an unbiased perspective. I was hooked for 6 hours and am typing this fast to jump back into bedlam :). FTL and XCOM are 10/10 games for me, this has elements of both and is a solid 7/10. As a final note, that the developers put so much effort into improving it (read other reviews) instills further confidence.

TLDR Conclusion:

Play FTL and if you like it, then this is different enough to be called its own game that has a lot of potential for replayability

reviewText:
When I first tried this game, shortly after it launched, I bounced off it within an hour. The art style was great and the writing was interesting and varied. The problem was, the gameplay itself just wasn't fun. The whole 2AP per side per turn was just too large a restriction on doing anything interesting and the necessity of needing to pick up resources during combat (they weren't rewarded afterwards) further messed up the flow of combat.

HOWEVER, to their great credit, the developers listened to their customers, and have spent the past several months revamping most of the game. The biggest change being that combat now functions like most other turn-based tactical isometric games; which is exactly what most people wanted. The combat itself is a little simple, due to the lack of activity abilities (other than the battlefield-wide dozer abilities). But between 4 classes, 5 factions, and the elite units there's enough passive differences to still allow for variety in combat.

And the result is that I'm having a lot of fun with the new REDUX version of the game. I can't spreak for other people, but bear in mind that reviews of the game that came out before March 2016 were reviewing a much different game than what it is now.

I do wish there were more unlockables than just the different types of dozers (your mobile home base), but that's the nature of rogue-likes I suppose. And if the developers continue to focus on improvements to the game, I would like some active abilites for units, at least some sort of overwatch system. But even if that doesn't happen, the developers deserve enormous credit for listening to their customers and doing so much work post-release on the game.

Its definitetely not perfect, but if you're looking for another turn-based tactical isometric game this is a pretty good option.

reviewText:
Never played the original version of the game, but since there's been a lot of patching going on since then and it's now version 3.0 I decided to give it a shot. I'm only an hour in so far but most problems people had with the game seem to have been fixed, especially the AP system (it's now 2 AP per unit instead of 2 AP for the entire crew).
I'll update this review once I'm further in, but so far it looks to be a fun and tough rogue-lite strategy game in a very cool post-apocalyptic world.

[Update] Alright, further in, finished campaign once (on normal), currently doing an arcade run (alternate game mode). Still loving the setting and the visuals, the drawings of the characters and little special events and everything are brilliant and probably one of the strongest pros for the game. The text events (FTL-style) have some nice humour and different outcomes (and special solutions if you got the right people in your Dozer), aren't that varied though. The different people you can meet are also very colorful, each with their own drawings and backstories. The fighting is kind of neither pro, nor con for me. It's decent and has its tense moments, but it's not really what keeps me playing (though the death animations are hilarious!).
All in all, I very much keep recommending this. There are some bugs, but the devs seem quite active and a fix for a bug I reported is supposed to drop tomorrow, so that's pretty neat.

reviewText:
I picked this game up after the Redux update, which changed the combat system (as well as a bunch of other stuff). Originally, you only had 2 action points per team per turn in combat, which means that larger teams were at a disadvantage. The new update simply gives each unit 2 action points, making that aspect play more like XCOM. It now pays to have a larger team in combat.

At this stage, I don't have a lot of detail to add to the review. I like the setting of the game and love the 2D art. Sound and music are good and unobtrusive. The strategic map offers interesting choices: do I go here and proceed with the story, or perform a side mission? Do I engage in a small battle for some resources? If I win, the threat level goes up and the difficulty increases: is that worth the rewards? Lots of interesting choices to be made.

In short, I thoroughly recommend this game if you're into turn-based strategy games.

reviewText:
This is a very good game. Not easy, but hours of fun and replayability. It dispenses with a lot of the standard BS and dumps you right into the action.

There is a significant learning curve to battle and you have to figure out how best to use the different types of fighters you have or you will quickly deplete your snipers and gunslingers (don't let Frontliners get too close to your Deadeyes and have Gunslingers behind cover nearly always). If you do not click on enemy soldiers to see how far they can move their next turn before you make your moves then you will find out that one of your hard earned upgraded fighters can get killed because you didn't move him far enough out of range from the enemy (the game is very much like chess in this regard). You also have to upgrade your Dozer carefully so you don't run out of crude or food. Along the way you try to pick up upgrades for your ride and new soldiers to fight for you in battles. The key to the game is gathering as many power cells as you can to use in battle and to upgrade your Dozer.

Graphics are pretty cool (Borderlands cartoon style). I have not yet come close to finishing the game on normal, but I just keep restarting and employing the tactics I learned the last time I got myself killed in Bedlam. All in all it is a pretty sweet little game to consume yourself in for a few hours at a time.

A lot of reviewers have criticized this game for its repetitive style and difficulty. Both are legit complaints, but I still enjoyed playing the game even though I was often frustrated. Plus, it's not like you're dropping $60 on a bad game, and upgrades and fixes are supposed to be coming.

reviewText:
This is the first I ever backed on kickstarter and after almost a year waiting, I finally was able to play the game and two words of description is Brutal Satisfaction.
First off: This game is hard, you will die alot. Do not feel discourage from this because like Madmax or any other wasteland, you gotta play hard to survive.
So what's the story? The trailer for the game explains it to you but basically you commaand some giant Truck called the Dozer full of people to take them to the mythical land of Aztec City. Yea I know, the name sucks get over it. But you'll be traveling across a giant ♥♥♥ wasteland that are controlled by 4 factions. These are the Mutants (Duh), the Cyborgs, Rogue AI and Marauders (Think madmax).
The gameplay is seperated into 2 different gameplay, Travel and Combat. Travel is where you direct where the Dozer travels to, similar to how FTL works. There are 3 resources that you will be managing, Meat, Fuel and PowerCell. The first two are crutial as you burn them when travel and can be replenished via some of the random events of the travel and during combat. Powercell, on the otherhand, is power used to upgrade the Dozer or use any super weapon/abilities during combat. During Travel, you might come by events that could grant you nothing, items, weapons, abilities, new crew or even a new dozer to try. Sometimes these random events can be ♥♥♥♥♥ and just kill you.
Combat is a seperate entity of the game. While the game may look like it's xcom or banner saga, it's really not. The controls are simplistic but really really difficult to master. Basically each turn consist of 2 moves similar to Xcom EU but you perform it for the amount of people you have on the field. The Enemy have the same condition but also have BLITZ, a special event where if the enemies aren't killed for a number of turns they will gain an extra move. This may be very challanging and discouraging majority of people but this also promotes quick thinking and strategy.
As for what else to  explain, I prefer for you to try the game out yourself. Hell, I haven't been able to beat the game once thanks to the difficulty of the game. And bloody hell am I not gonna give up on beating this game.

reviewText:
I picked it up following the redux update.
The art is pure joy, both static and in-combat animations.
However I did hold off hoping the reportedly flawed game design would mature a bit.

Now I wish this game would become the poster child for the virtues of long term support.

In short, it's brilliant.

Pros :
- Art is seriously top quality all throughout the game (check out the videos to see if you like the aesthetic).
- Core gameplay works flawlessly, in my mind much improved upon The Banner Saga formula.
- Replayability seems pretty good given the amount, quality and variety of content and unlocks.
- Game difficulty is well balanced, keeping you on your toes without ever feeling unfair (though Normal is a bit easy).
- RNG power is completely mitigated by the many strategic options, very explicit and transparent game info, and overall length of every run (unlike FTL for instance).
- Back story of each character and the writing in general is superb.
- Super parent friendly : can be paused between moves and events.

Cons :
- Although I found the writing great, the same events tend to reappear too many times in a single playthrough, somewhat breaking the immersion a bit.
- I wish I could sometimes have a way to improve my units a bit further, they max out pretty quickly (mid game for me).

TL;DR : if you like turn-by-turn strategic games, or just its art style, Bedlam is a very lovely experience and you should check it out.

Not going to spend a lot of time writing a review for this game, it's simply not worth my time. Apologies for the shortness... 3.5/10 for me. I did enjoy the graphics, but that's about it.

I bought this expecting a roguelike Xcom. But basically they throw you on a very small map with zero ways to prep and you get 2 moves. For those 2 moves you typically dive behind some cover if any randomly spawned around you. Then the computer takes it's 2 moves and kills one of your guys. Since you only had 2 moves you can't save everyone I guess. then you take your 2 moves and kill one of theirs. It gets old fast, zero strats involved.

Then you finish killing all the enemies, you get in your truck and randomly spawn on another small map and  guess what? Lose a guy, rinse, repeat until you're out of guys. There is some skill involved and a very slight learning curve, but only being able to move 1 single guy (out of your entire army) 2x, or 2 guys once, really doesn't give a lot of options or enjoyable game play. What can you really do with that? You can't really get a game plan together on such small maps, or devise any tactics. Maps are about 20x20 tiles. You pretty much count on the luck of the draw, where your troops randomly spawn, and where the enemy randomly spawns. You have zero control over what happens!

Then let's talk about troop combat. Your troops all have places where they can attack. Melee can attack adjacent which is fine. Shot gunners can attack a couple spaces and knockback, which is also fine. But anything else is complete garbage. Let's say you have a guy who can attack 6 spaces out in a circle around him, not 4, 5, or 7 mind you, it's exactly 6, otherwise you cannot touch him. Lets say you want to cover a tank as backup. The enemy just walks to 5 spaces shoots your guy and stands there. Now you have to waste both moves on your turn taking one step back and shooting him. There is no overwatch, so it's not like your sniper can sit there guarding someone. No, he has to waste his entire turn moving a single step back and then shotting the bad guy who is now exactly 6 blocks away. Most games you play, the shots get easier as you get closer and a higher chance to hit, not so in this game. you actually have to be the exact # of blocks away to make the shot. The enemy understands exactly where this range is and makes sure you have to waste both of your turns moving and shooting. It's probably one of the worse game mechanics I've seen this year in a turn based strat game.

So in closing, I should have watched a couple more youtube videos before purchasing this. I would have seen this game breaking flaw. Hopefully you can now learn from my mistakes and avoid this game until it goes on sale for $3.99 or something. Good luck!

reviewText: The way to enjoy Skyshine's BEDLAM is to treat it like FTL; a rouge like advenute where sometimes even with the best of planning bad things happen. And those bad things happen with a fair amount of requency, either in combat or while managing your convoy through the random encounters. So if you don't like permadeath or the board game Chess for that matter, this is likely not the game for you. I reference Chess because a lot of the games combat machanics revolve around spacial positioning and you have only 2 actions per turn for your whole side (up to 4 units per mission from your roster of crewmen). Units only have certain ranges they can attack and with low hit points coupled by the limited action, Chess makes a good comparison for how to approach the combat because you need to know how to cover the field have you units support each other. Much of the game is rouge like, but after a few playthoughs you'll have a good idea what to expect in the world of BEDLAM. Visually the game is like playing a graphic novel, much of the story is told from the point of view of the caravan as a whole as oppoed to individual characters. For the most part I like the feel of it all, although I still rage quit from time to time playing this game, and this is from someone who generally like to keep on playing through permadeth games like XCom & Darkest Dungeon. I'll look forward to more content and maybe an update or bod that'll let you position units before the start of a battle - the lack of which is my biggest gripe about the game. But I'd still reccomend it for those whom like games some stakes and odds just risky enough to keep you on the edge of your seat without walking away from the game.

reviewText:
Great little tactical game set up in an apocalyptical world !! The redux version is a huge improvement over the original. Arcade mode is now more action orieted and will satisfy your lust for endless battle. Campaign mode requires more careful resource management and route planning. The campaign map is set up in a way where you can take longer routes for better rewards but face the danger of running low on resources and have to expend precious power cells because chances are you will be facing more enemies.

Power cells are the most important resource in the game. Some negative reviews point out that the combat system is not as deep as Xcom but that is an unfair comparison, the game is not meant to be an Xcom clone. It emphasizes over-the-top weapons and animations in a humorous little package. Most of the tactics revolve around how you use your power cells. Do you want to AoE nuke your foes when they are bunched up or do you want to buff your squad members ? Some abilites are very powerful but the game is balanced in a way where you can't use them frequently. If you attempt to do so, you will eventually run out of juice and lose your precious levelled up team mates right there when you had Aztec City just in your sights.

Developers are constantly updating the game and interacting with the community I therefore expect the game will continue to improve.

reviewText:
I love squad based TBS games (Fallout 1 + 2, XCOM, etc etc) and I like the post-apocalyptic art in this game. What makes this game different from similar games is that instead of a turn order, you have two actions per turn to use per turn, and then the enemy makes two actions, etc. (Like Chess). The result of this is that even though you will be heavily outnumbered by the AI later in the game, it really doesn't matter as the AI can't move all its troops anyway. A lot of people complained about the game's difficulty, pointing to things like the AI faction teleporting units (this has been somewhat nerfed in the 1.5 patch), but I thought it was a suitable difficulty curve.

The game features four classes of units: Deadeyes (snipers), Frontliners (tanks), Gunslingers (pistolers) and Trenchers (shotgunners). With three kills, a rookie levels up to a Veteran (and gets a change of outfit to white), giving more hp and damage dealt. With every five more kills, the Veteran levels up, doing a further point of damage. This means that by the time you reach Aztec City, you should have Veterans at level 20-30, dealing 20+ damage per hit. To me this is an imbalanced mechanic as it favours certain classes over others. Deadeyes are close to useless in the late game due to their pitiful 5 hp as Veterans, meaning that they will be one shot killed regularly. Gunslingers I have found of limited value too. Trenchers are the stock troop of your army and you'll rack up a lot of kills with these guys. In my first successful playthrough, Maygrim reached level 30+ and had something like 150 kills. But now I've realised that Frontliners are BY FAR the best class due to their 7 movement and 12 hp as Veterans. Early they only do 2 damage, and then 4 after reaching Veteran, but if you nurse them through to level 10 or so they become godly, one shot killing anyone. In my second successful playthrough, I had Den on level 30 doing about 35 damage. That's overpowered and basically breaks the class system, as leveling up only gives more damage, not hp.

Travelling around Bedlam is relatively fun, but lacking variety. There are four enemy factions (Mutant, Marauder, Cyborg and AI) and some variety in the battles as each faction has a different mechanic, but once you learn what these are the variety fades. You'll need to upgrade your dozer to improve various efficiencies, but here I found that I maxed out the upgrades WAY too quickly, like within the first 30 mins of play. You'll encounter Elite enemies (helpfully signposted on the map when available), which join you when you defeat them. They are bigger (take up four squares), stronger (more dmg and hp) but seem to level up slower, so increasingly I have been using the normal units instead. It's harder to get them in cover too, on account of their size. Various random events will get you more units along the way, but you can't otherwise buy new units. As this is an Ironman game, you really need to babysit your team.

And this is where I encounter my main problem with this game and the thing that will kill its long term replayability unless patched somehow. There's a Bedlam meter rapidly increasing that encourages you to get to Aztec City quickly, but NO consequence if you don't do so. Sure, at Bedlam level there are more enemies, but due to the 2 move mechanic this really doesn't matter very much. It just makes the battles longer. The enemy troops basically DON'T get stronger, just more numerous. Because you need to level your guys up to 20+, and because you need a lot of power cells to defeat King Viscera, you basically need to grind your way around the map. In my first successful game, I spent over 600 days in game and explored basically the whole map, and in my second game I got bored by around 400 days. Just by exploring every side point of interest, you'll collect passengers, crude, meat and most importantly power cells. I had over 4000 food and crude and 600+ power cells by 400 days this time, meaning I could either grind some more or go straight to Aztec City.

One of the replayability factors is the unlocking of new dozers, but this is very hard (and random) to do. I unlocked my first dozer (Cyborg) after 27 hours, even after completely scouring the map on my first playthrough! And the dozers themselves aren't that interesting. I still haven't unlocked the other three dozers. There are some bugs, such as when you defeat E-Radik-8 and he's supposed to join you. He doesn't appear in your roster but DOES interact in some quests. This game needs more variety, more rewards for playing. Some of the achievements didn't work before the patch, and some aren't working after the patch. There needs to be some reason to stop trawling the map, because currently that is the way to win. The Bedlam meter goes up far too quickly, the upgrades are far too easy to get, and once you get your guys levelled the game is too easy and grindy overall.

These caveats aside, for a game I spent $16 on, 28 hours of play is a big win, even if I never played again. And I will. The devs addressed some of the issues in the 1.5 patch, and I'm hopeful that in time they might add more variety and spice to the game. Skyshine's Bedlam is a good indie game in the squad based TBS genre, and I've enjoying playing it and can recommend it to fans of the genre!

reviewText:
Take The Banner Saga, strip out the attempted epic story and replace it with a bite sized roguelike journey, and move the setting of the story up a couple thousand years to post-apocalyptica. Bam! You have Skyshine's Bedlam.

The aim of the game is to travel through dangerous unfriendly territory to reach your goal, which can only be reached by beating the final boss standing in your way at the end. Sounds familiar... but hey, everything's been done, and they've done it in their own style. It's a relentless, punishing, simple game, and while that simplicity stood in the way of The Banner Saga it really works here in Bedlam.

Do you like your games to beat you up? Give it a try!

Wait for sale or no? If you're a big fan of roguelikes it's worth $20, if you're not willing to replay over and over and over a game that wants you to fail miserably wait for a sale and buy it just for the art.

reviewText:
A bit biased on this being a kickstarter backer and all but here goes.

Skyshine's Bedlam is a rogue-like,rpg turned based with some x-com elements in it.

Gameplay and full walkthrough on my yt channel but beware spoilers.

Won't spoil the later part of the game but it does take quiet a twist from the usual genre of this game even I wasn't expecting so there is a ton of replayablity in this one.

Final score I'd give it an 8/10 as it does have some combat balance issues and I'd love to see some voice acting in this for more immersion and a little more encounter variety but this is Early Access after all.

So stop reading and buy already!

reviewText:
I'm a Bedlam fan. Love the mechanics, the characters and lore, tactics and arcade modes, the art, audio, strategy - pretty much all of it!

When it was first released though, it was pretty rough. Very unbalanced - in some releases it was playable but unwinnable. It has progressed substantially since launch.

I got through all the main missions and had a good time along the way. There are some kinks to work out still. Challenge Run is currently very unbalanced so I'm hoping that gets cleaned up soon.

full disclosure: I was a kickstart supporter and know one of the contributors

UPDATE AFTER 3.0

This is definitely the most solid release yet. More fun, better mechanics, more characters - a solid upgrade. There are some things I miss about 2.6 game play but they're overshadowed by the improvements in this release. Arcade mode and campaign modes are nicely differentiated and make sense (arcade mode in 2.6 didn't feel fully developed...). Challenge Run is gone - ha! I'll never quite know what they wanted to do with that mode.

Regardless, it's obvious the developers took the feedback and criticsm and made significant progress in making this a better game with each release. I still have fun with it!

reviewText:
Skyshine's BEDLAM is an interesting concept for a game to say the least. The Tactical RPG Strategy Roguelike combination is a brilliant blend and mixture of different genres, with the inclusion of an Invigorating Mad-Max word filled with rich lore and an unforgivingly psychopathic landscape truely makes the game feel grand and enjoyable. The Simplicity of the game and with the addition of the brilliant tactical battle system I kept on finding myself returning to the relentless Bedlam again and again.

However, after a while, It does start to feel ever so slightly tedious as there really only are only a couple events and each one having more or less the same exact outcome.  Added with the fact theres not really much to do in terms of exploration. I really want to explore the lore and the people of Bedlam and I feel there should be more aspects in terms of exploration and things to do in the Game. Maybe having NPC towns that are owned by a non-hostile faction that randomly dot the map a different time each gamemode. In the town you have the abillity to buy and sell supplies, maybe even buy and sell crew members and even do quests for extra rewards and goodies.

Thats my only real complaint of the game in general. However the game itself is still brilliant. The great artstyle and music really does give the game its overall charm and atmosphere. All in all the producers did a cracking great job at this game which hits the Tactica Stratlegy Roguelike combination straight on the head.

In my opinion, its worth the full £15 (or $20 for my American Buddies)

reviewText:
EDIT 9/25 Needless to say, my original review was not positive, but as I as I said, after the patch I will be updating.

I want to first give credit where it is due. The devs said they would address some of the biggest concerns and I feel they have done enough to justify a change on my review. (which you can find below)

If you are enjoy rouge-like/lite games then this should fill your need. There are enough elements to the game to make learning the best path take a few runs. After which you will be working toward getting the ending.

I want to point out that my only minor complaint is with the fact the game gives you plenty of champs to fight with, but for the most part they are useless still. This doesn't really impact the game in a negative way, so I can't take points off. Just would be nice to see each of these champs be unquie or give value to them other then wasted meat to sheild my elites.

Old Review

TL:DR - In combat there is a 50/50 chance every encounter that enemies will be placed right next to you, or one of your champs is placed right next to them (this is not a good thing). Nothing you do, sort of cheesing (using an OP item) will prepare you for the end game. Getting extra characters is almost pointless (nothing will replace the guy you just lost with 23 kills).

My extended thoughts
End game
I was expecting some RNG tactical game where you build up a squad of fighters to go toe-to-toe with a big bad boss. After an epic battle, I would get a gratifying feeling knowing that I played my cards right with progression, that RNGesus blessed me just enough and my tactics were sound.

At this point, I feel no sense of achievement. On my first play-through, I did not lose anyone, had a badass sniper that did 12 damage (thats alot) and a squad of strong champs. Then the ending happened.

****spoilers****


Mutant king form is unreasonably strong. I didn't have the one equalizer that heals when you get hit (didn't even know it existed on my first play) and I got rekt. What is worse? when you go to fight him again your whole epic party is gone and the whole fight starts over. You literally have 1 chance to beat him. There is no battle of attrition.

Combat-
I like the 2 turn thing. More realistic then a whole team moving.
The rock, paper, scissors feel to each character is alright.
The blitz mechanic gives a feeling of pressure to keep moving

Biggest game ruiner for combat is the random placement at the start of combat. I can deal with not being able to place my team exactly, but the idea that the enemy can be placed behind my line is absurd. Imagine starting off where you are in a position to lose two champs at the START. I echo what someone else said- I would never place my team like that" and add how did they get that close without getting shot first.

Everything else
Pretty much everything else in the game is exactly as you would expect. I really enjoy 90% of the game. The look is great. The resource system. The map etc...

Until the issues above have been corrected though
date: I just cannot recommend the game. The devs say they are listening and plan on releasing an update. I will be back and will change my opinion if things change to fix these heart breaking issues."

After being informed about the Redux version of Bedlam I decided to jump back in and see what had changed. Personally I'm so happy with the new changes to combat it's made a huge difference to me. https://youtu.be/JcUFx8vWyew

I loved the look of this game when I first saw the title. I'm a fan of rogue like games & the stories they can create comapred to someone else. Bedlam was looking to be a strong game with some great design. I love the combat animations and the environment. Sadly the main part of this game the combat feels dull rather than strategic. You get 2 actions across your entire team as does the enemy. So that one move one attack or 2 moves etc etc. However I often find both me and the AI are using one character for both our action points until one of us  loses that fighter then we move onto the next. The rest of our team just waiting patiently in the corner watching the action happen until it's their turn to be thrown into slaughter. The game is hard I won't deny which I do like. Leveling up a character if you can make them live that long and get enough kills will gain veterancy and start to just become all round better fighters. The challenge is a good challenge but where I thought I'd find myself loving the wasteland combat and losing my mind if I scored that lucky headshot or one of my best fighters just got butchered I'm finding myself sighing whenever combat begins. Not what I expected at all and it's a shame. The animations in combat are great so not getting to see them at their full potential kinda saddens me. As much as I want to I generally don't think I could recommend this game. Hopefully they make a seperate combat mode as a difficulty setting or their future games take a longer look at their combat.

reviewText:
Great concept with poor execution, Skyshine's Bedlam could be good but definitely feels like it needed a proper Early Access period.

With shallow exploration, poor resource management, a lack of real choice in event decisions, no dozer customization, little difference between unlocked dozers and no real interactivity between the world and your crew, there isn't much reason to play through more than a few times. The lack of anything interesting makes combat the main-focus, which is a love or hate affair; a poor example of games like FTL.

Currently, the game is an un-advertised Early Access title. Previous updates show a lack of direction on the developer's part with respect to the future  for their game, as they continue to experiment with features that should have been nailed down before an official release.

If you're interested, wait for a sale. Although combat is controversial, there are many other issues that make the title disappointing.

Since my last review Skyshine has really had a chance to shine ('scuse the pun).
The developers have been listening to players to address the issues people have had. This is a game that's always had great character and potential, and is now worth picking up. I can finally enjoy the game I've been waiting for.

OLD REVIEW:

The concept and style of the game coupled together was an instant YES from me.
However, the combat system feels clunky and unfair (the opposing force tends to have more players and better placing). I'd like to have seen each class with a more distinguished play style, perhaps a special move that uses up both turns to be able to use.
Something like:
Grenades for Trenchers (like the enemy have)
Flurry attack for Frontliners (multiple hits with a 50-50 chance of hitting)
Overwatch style mechanic for snipers...I mean Deadeyes
Sprint move for Gunslingers
Again these are just basic ideas but I feel as though they would have given the combat a lot more depth.

If you're looking at getting this game you should ask yourself one question...

Did you like The Banner Saga or FTL?
A) Yes - Go and play those

reviewText:
ALRIGHTY EVERYONE THIS REVIEW IS BEING REDONE!

Okay so befor I say anything, Major... MAJOR props to the devs. They've come a VERY long way from their restart and have worked closley with the community and taken all their feedback to make this game great.

Okay, now to the actual game. It takes place in a post-nuclear world where your objective is to get your passangers across the wasteland from the only safe city known to the planet called Byzantine to a mysterious and legendary floating palace that is the only true safe haven called Azctec City. You use a veichal called a Dozer to traverse the wastelands which comes equipped with different weapons and battlefield upgrades.

Traversing the Wasteland: You have X amount of Food, Crude (Fuel), Power Cells, and Passangers. Food and Crude are consumed daily, when you travel from one place to another x amount of food and crude is consumed for x amount of days it takes to get there. You can use power cells to upgrade your dozer or use it's weapons on the battlefield. Upgrades consist of Reduced Food and Crude consumption, Reduced amount if time it takes for combative crew members to heal, or reduce the amount of power cells it takes to use dozer weapons. Upon starting a game you may chose which faction you want your crew to be.

Factions: Humans, Rouge AI, Mutants, Marauders, and Cyborgs.
Humans: Well.... They're kinda average. Nothing special about them. At all. (As far as I can tell)
Mutants: Every time their cobmative turn comes up they regain one HP.
Cyborgs: Every turn they lose one HP but gain one Damage (This ability will not kill them, when they reach low enough health they will no longer gain damage and will not lose health)
Rouge AI: Every few Turns they become invulnerable to damage
Mauraders: Every few turns they gain the ability to move a few extra spaces.

The Crew: This consists of all the four classes and ranks of crew members.
While selecting your Dozer and Faction, you also get to choose from four crew setups.
No Leader, No Elites, No Veterans, 12 Rookies.
No leader, 0 Elites, 3 Vets, 8 Rooks. Leader, 0 Elites, 1 Vet, 7 Rookies.
Or Leader, One Elite, No vets and 5 Rookies.

Leaders are a unit specific to the dozer but some can also be found as a weakend version of itself as an Elite. Leaders are very powerful. Elites can be found in the wastelands and are also powerful, Rookies are your average crew members that, if they achieve three kills become a veteran.

The four classes consist of Gunslingers, Deadeyes, Trenchers and Frontliners.
Gunslingers: Dual pistols, medium agility, medium damage, High Health. If hit from a target within their firing pattern they return fire.
Trenchers: Shotguns, High agility, Higher damage, Medium Health and has knockback. If next to their target they ignore the benefit of cover.
Frontliners: Highest agility, Lowest damage, Most agile. Considered to be the tanks of the crew and they only attack with Meele, Baton and shield. Always ignores cover.
Deadeye: Lowest agility, Highest damage, Lowest health. Can inflict immense damage and if lucky achieves an instant kill headshot. Snipers of the crew, but very fragile.

This isn't like XCom where you can attack in a certain range, each class has a shooting PATTERN, it's hard to explain you're better off looking up gameplay and looking for the red dots as people move and shoot. After successfully completing a combative encounter you gain resources immedietly. If you lose, you either lost all your deployed crew (4 people) or fled. Upon losing passangers leave the dozer.

There are two modes, Tactics mode and Arcade mode. In tactics mode each squad member gets two turns, if they fire upon their second turn their attack only does 60% damage. (Please note, later in the game the enemy has MORE units then you do and WILL overwhelm you if you do not make use of your dozer weapons. Upgrade earlier, so you don't need to be afraid of using your powercells later.) I'll be honest, I don't play much of Arcade mode so I won't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you about it. I can't help you there, I'll come back and edit this section later.

To win you must traverse the wasteland and find four artifacts, then fight the supreme ruler of the Wastelands, King Viscera. While traveling to find these artifacts you may come across resources, but more importantly Points of Interest. POIs can be anything, from simply a fight, to stumbling upon a new recruit, all the way to finding new battle upgrades and weapons for the dozer. Also equally as important are Elites. Elites as mentioned befor are powerfull units that can put up a real fight. To achieve these units, you must find them marked on the map and defeat them in combat. This will go a long way in helping you get to Aztec city.

SO I would definetly recommend this game and I must give huge props to the devs for sticking with this game for oh so very long and making it great, working closely with the communits. I'll summarise quickly at the end here but please read the whole thing. <3

Pros:
- Beautiful Artwork/Graphics
- Clear path to goals via tutorials.
- You feel accomplished after finishing a run and unlocking the next dozer.
- Combat is quick to get used to and easy to learn
- Character designes for Elites and Humans are pretty cool.

Cons:
- Traversal system is just a little bit unclear... At times you'll want to get to somewhere on the map, but the problem being is you can't see movment options past either what is immedietly available or what has already been traveresed, so sometimes you'll be RIGHT NEXT TO your destination, but you can't go to it and have to go to three other places first without knowing how many places you'll need to travel or which path to chose (major waste of resources) but it's usually dealable and dosn't get too bad.
- The combative system in this game IS NOT for everyone. Some people will despise the way in which classes are set up to be able to shoot in a pattern instead of a range. Example: Your dual pistoled gun slingers become stupid and can't bring themselves to shoot someont standing right infront of them because they have to be X amount of tiles away, in a certain tile pattern away from the gunslinger. (This is for all classes, in different patterns.)
- Crew designes for factions other then humans get dull. All the Females have one portrait and all the Males have one. The Humans are the only ones with diversity. And they don't have an ability (as far as I can tell).

And that pretty much sums it up! After reading this you should look up some videos befor buying it to really be sure if this game is for you. It's a good game now, a really good game. But it is not for everyone. At all. HUGE props to the devs though! Go check out their other games, give em some support. ^^

UPDATED 20160331!

With the REDUX overhaul and the intense, impressive work that the dev team has done, this game has really grown into it's potential.

Rather than just axe the elements that some players had issue with, they made them optional and really listened to the community and, more importantly, continue to remain engaged!

Bravo Skyshine!

reviewText:
After the developers released the REDUX update to this game, I gave it another whirl and I am glad I did.  Below are a few points that I thought were improved:

Combat system

Oh man, this is so much better than the last time I played.  Each character on the battlefield gets 2 actions per turn now instead of a shared pool of actions.  Also, there is now a penalty for decreased damage done that round if you have to move your character, which rewards players for thiking ahead and placing characters in strategic positions.

Resource collection

So far i have only played the campaign version of the game, not the arcade, but I love that resources are now provided to you after a successful battle instead of you having to manually pick them up during the battle themselves.

Additional death animations

I love the enemy death animaltions when killed by your sniper, however, the frontliner's bad ♥♥♥ elbow drop is still my favorite.

All in all, this game is way more awesome since the REDUX update, and I will be spending more time with it.

reviewText:
The art is nice but there is very little of it and it gets reused a lot. It is way too expensive just for a bunch of artworks.

The characters you recruit all have a badass biography but they actually have the same stats as the lower ennemy mooks.

The first time a character levels it gets a significant boost in all its stats (dmg/health/range/mvt) and gets a full heal (btw the new costume is crap). The next levels only increases your dmg by 1 each time. You don't get to choose which stat to upgrade. There is no perks or skill tree.

The level system is completely broken since the only stat that change is dmg and there is no level/stat cap.
A soldier starts with 5 dmg and can level to 100 dmg if you grind enough. The consequence is that you can 1 or 2 shoot bosses. It is even more ridiculous with sniper units that stay at very low health: they can one shoot anything but any random mook can one shot them.

You can recruit elites. Elites tend to have more health and more limited movement but any over-leveled unit you have will deal considerably more damage.

You can unlock extra dozers but they don't get unique abilities or weapons. Their screens use the same art as the starting dozer even if the current dozer is a giant mutant creature. The APC unit is the same for all dozers. The starting crew of a faction dozer is not fully staffed with unit from this faction.

The enemies are basically all the same but with a different skin and a lame ability on top. Mutants should rarely use guns but instead use mutant abilities (acid spit, spikes, tentacles/extensible tongue, etc.). Some factions should have pets (war dogs for marauders, mutant beasts for mutants). Factions should differ in numbers, abilities, stats and technological level

The combat is crap but could be easily improved:
-allows 4 ap by turn with a limit of 2 ap by unit
-introduce special abilities (the gunslinger can throw grenades for instance)
-introduce special attacks: charged/spread shot - a minigunner may be able to hit multiple targets at once. This is one of the biggest issue with combat: you have to slowly take out ennemies one by one and you can have 10+ at the same time.
-implement a real cover system
-give the unit the ability to carry items in battle
-have not all the battles be with a ton of low level mook but have battles with less enemies but more veteran/elite enemies.
-have more weapons on the dozer but with a tiered system (the more powerful a weapon the more it costs in energy, has a longer cool-down, may actually require a specific ressource such as individual nukes)
-have unit movement & range makes sense
-weapons & powers may cost less but have cool downs & the amount of energy may be capped
-have new classes (the rocket cyborg shouldn't be treated as a sniper) & hybrid classes


The combat is bad but what is much worse is the complete lack of content and replayability: you will get the same events over and over with the same outcome. Also there is too much points of interest their number should dwindle the more you explore a location.  Interesting point of interest that require a specific item  should stay on the map so that you can revisit them later when you find the item. Of course there is also way too many battles. It gets old extremely fast.
The game is also lacing events such as mechanical problems, freak climatic events, conflicts inside the dozer, etc.
There is no choices & consequences. The game is missing towns where you can trade resources & recruit dudes.

Some mechanisms do not make any sense:
-Why do 300 passengers flee after a lost or abandoned battle ? They will die in the wasteland.
-Why can I recruit passengers from warring factions ? It will bring war to the dozer.
-Why the marauder dozer can recruit cyborgs their sworn ennemies and vice-versa ?
-Why does the mutant dozer consume crude ?
-Why can I sell my passengers to slavers or merchants to get ressources ?

reviewText:
This is a case of trying to cover poor mechanical choice by claiming that it makes for a challenge. Interesting ideas hampered by appauling lack of consideration

This game is closer to chess than it is x-com, with the move limit being 2 per turn for the entire squad rather than a move per unit. You also tend to find your units in a Dead or Not dead situation, simmilar to being taken" in chess rather than actualy having a hope in hell of surviving.

The issue is unlike chess you cannot afford to sacrifice units in this game. you have a finite number of troops per run and no way of reliably getting more. Compound this by the game forcing you to gamble for resources and random events which may kill you but are still crucial to being able to advance and you have a game that is frustrating in how harshly you are punished
date: while at the same time it forces you to make these bad choices.\n\nEach unit was clearly meant to fill a certain role but that gets a little fuzzy because they all perform the same two actions
recommended: move and shoot. Sniper = damage dealer
hoursPlayed: Frontline = meat shield
voteText: Gunslinger = generalist risk taker
helpfulPercent: trencher = target practice. reviewText:
It's an alright game. Just be aware that the combat system is like that in The Banner Saga, not like that in Shadowrun / Fallout 1/2/Tactics / Divinity:Original Sin / etc. - your characters don't have individual action points, but each side in the conflict get 2 moves each round, to spend on moving or attacking.

Well, and sometimes your enemies get 3 moves if you don't kill any of them over enough turns in a row, presumably to keep you from just sitting there doing nothing while your enemy has to spend all their moves to get in range to attack you - only to not be able to attack because they're now out of moves - allowing you to blast them to pieces effortlessly during your turn since now they're in range.

Anyway, it's just sad that it gets so annoying a few hours in. Sure, if you can deal with the combat system, it's a pretty good game for the first few hours. Pretty simplistic, but entertaining enough. Then you make it to the aztec city, and turn around to fight king viscera. He's pretty hard, but you manage to beat him, probably at the cost of a good chunk of your stored up power and probably a couple of your best fighters. Then you face him again. And again. And again. And by the third or fourth time, you're either completely out of characters strong enough to actually fight him, or you're out of the power required to use the 'equalizers' necessary to have king viscera not just kill one of your characters every turn.

The game's combat system reveals itself to be very broken in situations where one side has a character vastly more powerful than anyone on the other side. Your characters have 5-20 health and do 5-10 damage per attack, while your enemy's character has 60+ health and does 10+ damage every attack.

So what happens is just he walks up to your characters with his 2 action moves, you shoot him twice with your action moves, then the next turn he kills 1-2 of your characters (unless you spent moves running out of range of him, in which case you weren't shooting him, never mind how you just have him BLITZ points, which generate when you're not attacking, so if you do that enough he gets a 3-move turn), then you shoot him 2 more times, then he kills your 2 remaining characters and you lose. Only way to actually beat him is use 'equalizers' that keep your characters from dying every turn, but those cost power and power is limited.

Only way I can even imagine being able to beat the game is by, in a very un-roguelike fashion, literally spending hours (with no savegame feature as far as I can tell) grinding in the wasteland to gather enough power to be able to spam equalizers constantly during the king viscera fights.

Overall... I want to recommend this, but I just can't. The first few hours are pretty good, but the final part of the game is just, well, not very.

reviewText:
It saddens me to give something this new a negative review.  I'm sort of new to the whole XCOM-type combat system, but I've played a little bit of it and it's very simple to figure out.  It's literally chess.  Some units can attack with only 1 space of range, some give you a much broader attack range (like a shotgun, for example), and some require a certain distance (a rifle unit cannot attack unless they are a certain number of spaces away from the target).

Well... the idea, and the combat, is fine... but the problem I have is how the game progresses.  There's no skirmish mode, campaign mode, or any of that stuff.  There's only one type of game mode, and that's the roguelike thing where you drive around this big truck on a giant map with a countless number of random events.  In between battles, your units basically don't heal at all.  It says like, 25 days to heal each unit, so basically do not expect a single hit point to be healed ever.  If they die, they're dead forever.  You have a limited number of units, fuel, and meat.  You can pick up fuel and meat on the battlefield, at the end of the battles, sometimes in random events they are given to you, and you may even find a meat/oil trader along the way.

You are given meat and oil bonuses if you take a fewer number of units on the battlefield, but since you can take as long as you want in between turns, I always take the full 6 units out with me, this gives me a much broader choice of actions.  So your 6 units are placed on a battlefield against their 6 units.  The amount of damage each unit does and the amount of hit points they have varies, but you and your opponent are equally matched.  Often times I would lose 2 or 3 units, since they die on 1 hit most of the time!  Some enemies doing upwards of 5-6 damage, when your units may only have 2-5 health.  The units which have 10 health, which is actually a pretty decent amount, only 2 damage to your enemy, and can only attack one single space in front of them.  Since they'll have to attack numerous times to take anyone down, you can expect them to be at least half dead after each enemy.  Remember, there's no healing in this game either.

Let's say you played a game of chess against someone, and you lost half of your chess pieces, would you feel confident enough to face another opponent using your remaining pieces?  I don't think anyone's ever tried doing that before, a sort of 'survival' chess...  Probably because it's not that good of an idea.  Yet this game embraces doing exactly that.

You start with 16 units.  After 3 or 4 battles, you'll be lucky to have 6 good ones left.  The enemies will slowly chip away at your team.  And so far the only way I have found to recruit extra team members is to defeat a boss, then the boss joins you.  This is a really cool feature, actually, but those bosses do like 7-9 damage per hit.  You might be able to take him down with 3 well placed rifle shots but they are not easy to kill, and you may end up losing half your team in the process.  It sounds easy enough, right?  Shoot him a few times.  But the unit movement is very awkward, you will lose turns trying to line up your shots.  Sometimes you can kill them with ease, but they also have equal opporntunity to kill you with ease.  And they do.

So basically, I have not survived more than 18 minutes before getting a game over.  I'm not big into reading the long dialogs so I just skip them and get right into the combat as soon as I can.  When it's 6 against 6, there's a good chance I lose a unit or two in battle.  After 4 battles, I barely have anyone left.  Then it's game over.  Is this really all there is to this game?  I think this game would be better off if I had twice as many units, or twice as many hit points, or something.  I'm playing on the easy difficulty, too.  Never tried normal.  And I still can't seem to last 20 minutes.  The gameplay isn't rocket science.  You move into range, click to attack, then they do their turn, either killing you instantly or cutting your health in half.

I wouldn't recommend this game.  Seems a few other reviewers are also having the same experience, but not all.  The developers have even said in the discussions that they are working on balancing the combat system...  They should have done that prior to release in my opinion.  I can't give them tips on how to improve it, though, as the concept sounds great but it's just awful in practice.  I didn't even get into detail of the limited fuel and how annoying it is to get a game over because you run out of fuel.  You have 1000 fuel to start.  It takes anywhere from 30 to 200 fuel to move your truck a space.  That's another aspect to manage and it runs out very quickly.  Move your truck 5 times and then it's game over, play the whole thing over from the beginning!  Rediculous.  Just play XCOM, if you are into these types of games, at least that game gives you a fighting chance.

The shield-bearers can now provide cover... well if I could fire around cover that would mean something, but as it is they usually manage to distract the enemy shotgunners for one, maybe two attacks before being put down, and even then you'll most likely have to reposition a character to counterattack.

Also... didn't we used to be able to attack twice if we didn't move?  That got taken away?

The Equalizers still cost a ridiculous amount of resources to use, so even if they do have new fuel types to use it's not worth it.

Map's still random, even trying to plot a course to take advantage of crude locations can lead to lots of backtracking and running short just before the end.

I see it's gotten a lot more positive recommendations, and I'm not really sure how that happened but maybe it appeals to the Dark Souls / Darkest Dungeon crowd who like being supremely frustrated by games.  I'm not one of those people, so maybe the game's just not for me.

reviewText:
-- DISCLAIMER--
This review predates the large REDUX update and will be revised in future. Please take this into consideration if you choose to read on

-------------------


So, Skyshine's BELDAM. Where to begin...

This game, as with many others like it, falls into the cracks made by FTLs earth-shattering redefinition of the roguelike genre. It's so painfully, agonisingly close to a good game but for me it just doesn't quite measure up. Let me cover this bit by bit so I don't miss anything out.

The Dozer. You'd think this'd be a decent chunk of the game considering the amount of work that's gone into it's art and how it's front-and-centre of the games lore, but it doesn't feel like you're in one at all. It lacks primarily in two ways.
First, the dozer is presented as a sort of Ark for people looking to make it to Aztec City. The number in the dozer menu says you have 1,000 souls on board, but it might as well be zero as they don't have any bearing on the gameplay. They can be traded away to various encounters just like fuel, meat or power cells. The Banner Saga wracked me with guilt and anguish by visibly seeing people abandoning the caravan or starving to death. In this? Gimme the power cells!
Secondly, the dozer has very limited gameplay influence. Outside of bombardments, it's absent from combat. You frequently fight inside it, but this just means you can't use bombardments and if you lose this particular fight it's game over (negative reinforcement gaming booo). You can (re: must) spend power cells on upgrading various efficiencies, but there's no choice here, no interesting decision to weigh up. Your best choice is to upgrade them all when you can. This is neither FTL nor Convoy in highlighting strengths and weaknesses of a given vehicle. It's just a thing you see on a map.

The combat. The difficulty spikes and troughs are gargantuan. The early-game is incredibly difficult. You'll lose virtually irreplaceable rookie units at a steady rate through no fault of your own. The enemy plays by the same rules as you do, but with a much less greater sense of self-preservation. They'll move their guys into suicidal positions to kill someone on your side, and while it's no big deal for them in this random battle, steady losses means your guys don't live long enough to level up and be useful. Playing in any way other than perfectly defensive will lead to heavy losses that you can't claw back from. Better units are recruited only by defeating them, so if you've already got a depleted roster and lose a few more trying to recruit a heavy hitter...
If you're able to keep one or two rookies alive long enough to get 3 or more kills, they become significantly more useful. Recruiting said heavy hitters then become much easier, who drastically improve your roster further, and from then on until near the end of the game it's easy street. I've only encountered the end few fights once but holy Moses does the difficulty explode to astronomical levels again.
Both ways that the game handles increasing difficulty are unpalatable. In one way they turn guys into massive bullet-sponges (which is unsatisfying as you've worked so hard to have upgraded soldiers to just have it negated ) and the other by drastically increasing the number of enemies (which is also unsatisfying because they still only get two actions a turn, so you end up churning through a steady trickle of weak enemies, which make you a lot stronger a lot quicker). The enemies themselves stay the same in terms of weapon and movement range.
My overall impression of the combat is that there is one correct way to win, not many ways to win.

Don't even get me started on how the Robot AI enemy-type blatantly cheats. They can teleport to what appears to be anywhere else on the map for an action. So while you've got a front line of defenders and you've made sure that your heavy-hitting snipers are well out of the way of suicidal dives by the enemy, they'll teleport well beyond their movement range and one-shot the sniper. Thanks, game! Super jerk-like of you.

The story stands on it's own two feet in terms of having its own tone in a crowded genre, but the presentation falls flat. In FTL you come across encounters that are risk/reward based on who you've got on your crew and what type of ship/weapons you've got. So far I haven't encountered a single negative affect from investigating every text-based offer presented to me. Many encounters will just be story with no choice and no resources gained or lost, so it feels like a waste of time. You don't really encounter stores, just people willing to trade, but you're never told how much you're going to get or how much you're going to trade.


tl,dr: Garhhhh this game has so much potential! So many things are already there and in place and working that could turn this into something fantastic. Certainly not FTL level, but at least up there with The Banner Saga. But alas, no. The 'base' of the dozer is very underutilised in gameplay, the combat frequently feels cheap and lacks a lot of strategy found in similar titles, the encounters feature heavy repetition and little if any risk...

I can't recommend this game even for fans of the genre as you're better off playing something I've mentioned earlier. It's so bloody frustrating, this could've been great! I can see it through all it's shortcomings, it's 95% of the way there... But no, it's not. This isn't the game I hoped it would be.

reviewText:
Skyshine's Bedlam is a strange, strange game, with cool ideas, great game feel, and a completely anti-fun combat system. This game feels like it should be in early access. Videos of my run will follow, to prove my points.

It's odd limitations make it beneficial to bring nearly no soldiers into battle. I found that 3 soldiers were enough. Until the near end of the game, I brought 3 soldiers every fight, and had so many resources I couldn't use them all. the core thing to realize is that bringing more troops DOESN'T make you more safe. It just means you lose more troops. You'll generally end each fight with 3 troops, whether you bring 3 or 6. The way the engine works is simple. 2 actions for me, 2 for you. Any of my pieces can use the actions on my turn. This means that numerical advantages really don't matter at all, and in fact are a kind of disadvantage. A force of 3 can move together, cover themselves, and pick off the flanks. The large force can only move, at most, 2 pieces a turn, meaning it's esstially a Thermopolae situation every fight. The player forces stand back, hold position, and let the opponents run into a gauntlet of fire until they're all dead.

The class system is a good idea that is executed poorly. The sniper class is literally useless. They start with 2 HP, and can move 3 spaces. They do good damage, but it doesn't matter, because the next class makes them useless.

The Frontline can move 6 squares, has 10 HP and does 2 damage. One hit from any enemy kills any rookie sniper. And the AI targets them 100%. I actually started bring rookie snipers to bait the trap for the AI, because they make it the top priority to kill them, ignoring everything else.

The shotgun class often ends up killing itself, by blasting targets out of their own range. Basically useless.

The only class I found really useful was the Gunslinger, who had decent range and decent damage, although the class ability (When attacked, you return fire) never worked properly. It would happen sometimes, but not others, with no explanation of why that would be.

The random placement of your troops, often within shooting range of the enemy, leads to a mad scramble that results in multiple deaths on your side before you even get to fire a shot.

On my first run, I made it across Bedlam, but by the 30 minute mark I found that I didn't care. The upgrades to the dozer were maxed out in the first province, and the few people who survived their first encounters were far too strong.

The designers realized, or course, that this game would revolve around players biding their time and waiting, as the enemies charged at them (as seen by the Blitz meter at the top of the screen, more on that in a minute), but the AI is so useless that turn after turn, 2 enemies would move into range, and both would be immediately killed on my turn. On the next AI turn, they'd send 2 more to their doom, for no reason. Some of the enemies have grenades (which you don't have, by the way), and when they target 3 of your people, you don't get to attack that turn. You have to move 2 people out of the way, and the 3rd still gets hit.

This game has a lot of cool ideas. I like the Dozer, I like the resources, but again, I was never even CLOSE to running out of any resource. EVER. Except power, which I spent carelessly and freely the whole game long.

Upon fighting a named boss, you will, guaranteed, lose a crew member. The bosses do 7-9 damage, and the only member of your crew that has more than 9 health cannot do enough damage to kill a named boss. There are just so many problems. I want to like this game. I think it has great combat animations, and the grid system and cover mechanic is nice, although I wish they had a % chance to hit shown, instead of random guess. I also wish cover worked sensibly, where you could shoot over your cover on your turn, and hide during the other side's turn. I wish that being in cover" didn't help you when I'm shooting you in the back from the same side of the cover.

Now
date: let's talk about the Blitzmeter.\n\nThe game teaches you NOTHING about it. There's a random tip on the loading screen that informs you that when it fills up
hoursPlayed: instead of 2. It doesn't tell you that killing an enemy resets the counter. It also doesn't tell you that enemies can move farther during their blitz action. This is not the kind of thing that is "a cool trick" that players need to learn by playing

reviewText:
My experience with this game is a little different than most reviewers.

For one, i really liked the battle system. Sure it makes no thematic sense to have just two actions for the whole team, but there is a lot of strategy and risk management involved. Apart from the last battle, i didn´t find the game´s difficulty to be unbearable.

However, when i FINALLY defeated the last boss, guess what? The game froze. That´s it, no ending score, no achievements, nothing. I turn to the forums and find out that EVERYONE WHO BEATED THE GAME IS HAVING THE SAME PROBLEM.

So, to sum it up:

PROS:
+The art style is really well done. The characters are stylish and each drawing is a joy to see.
+ I loved the battle system. It´s tense and makes you think. Most people won´t like it though.

CONS:
- The writing is terrible. 80% of the words in each paragraph are made up. For people that do not have english as a native language, it´s almost incomprehensible. Plus, the lore and events are bland and uninteresting, and do not impact the gameplay in any meaningful way.

- The events are also poorly scripted. You get a lot of items in your journey, but very, very rarely get the chance to use any of them. And when you finally do, the payoff is disappointing. The events also often repeat, so there´s not much replay value.

- After a lot of hours, and tense battles, when you finally complete your mission, THE GAME FREEZES WITH NO VICTORY SCREEN. And this is not an isolated ocurrence. Honestly, this is unacceptable.

Conclusion: Unfortunately, this game is simply not worth the asking price. Even if they fixed the problem with the ending, it would still be advisable to wait for a major sale before you consider buying it.

reviewText:
I really hate to 'not recommend' this game considering the beauty and obvious effort put into it.  However, I have to be honest and say it's simply not up to release or genre standards.  If there are adjustments made I will be happy to change my review to 'recommend' but for now I'd hold out on purchasing.

(EDIT: I said I would be happy to change my review if changes were made; perhaps I should have been clear that I meant 'changes that come quick before I stop caring'.  It's been six months; I stopped caring or holding out for change long ago.)

I want to start by saying this game really isn't difficult- it's just badly designed.  Battles are wildly random with regards to initial unit placement and having a good/bad encounter can depend entirely on where your troops are stationed when the battle starts.  Add to that a forced encounter as soon as you leave the city and the entire run can be stalled right out of the gate leading to simple resets until you get a favorable first encounter.

I'm not complaining that it's 'too hard' because once you figure the battle system it's really quite simple.  Deadeyes (and their Veteran upgrades) are completely broken in regards to the other classes and you can take out the majority of 'recruitable' bosses with 2 Deadeyes alone.  The game 'balances' this by making every AI enemy rush straight for your snipers which, again, can make or break an encounter depending on where your troops spawned in.

Other classes have wonky ranges that don't make sense.  Both 'mid-range' classes (the Gunslinger and the Shotgunners- can't remember what they're called because I never use them) can't fire directly in front of themselves forcing 'no-win' situations if an enemy gets close.  IE: if an enemy comes close, you have to move then shoot taking two turns which means you can't get the kill and at least one unit will for sure die.  It's clear the developers didn't grasp what makes a good tactical shooter/RPG.

It is important to note the issues with the battle system because that's all this game really has.  You'll quickly find the game is quite shallow (in comparision to games like FTL or other modern Roguelikes) and so far it seems that 90% of all POIs are either A) have item = get resources B) get item needed for 'A' C) get resources D) start battle encounter.  There's no real 'choice' or varying consequences.  I've only been playing for a few hours but I feel like I've seen everything to see.

In one run you could be swimming in resources by the halfway point, blowing through enemies left and right and the next run you rapidly lose every unit you have because of bad encounter positions.  I understand Roguelikes can be punishing but bad and random design isn't challenging, it's just that- random.

Outside of the battle system you'll find a UI that lacks usability and is overly cluttered.  Lots of encounter dialogs filled with made up words but lacking basic grammar proofreading.  Glitches galore, crashes, and missing assets; the worst is the lack of sound options (other than ON/OFF) because the sound effects are so drastically loud it's nonsensical.  No video options either...

It seems like this could have been a really amazing game with heart, a solid aesthetic, and building on a genre we all know and love but it comes out half-baked, lacking content, polish, and even basic necessities for a release.  Most offensive is that it doesn't seem to understand ITSELF (every single tactical RPG I've ever played has a 'deploy phase', now I understand why) and punishes the player for it.  Here's hoping they get it figured out and update the release before abandoning this to mediocre reviews.

EDIT: So apparently a 'Redux' version has come out and a developer (SkyshineJeff") has tried to post an addendum to my post letting readers know this review is for an old version of the game.  That's a complete load.  I payed full listing price 6 months ago for a barebones
recommended: poorly thought out attempt at a tactical roguelike.  I gave it my best and after 5 hours (past the point of refund) I posted a review.  Half a year later the developer 'fixes' the issues and tries to reverse the negative reaction.\n\nIt's too late.  This was the bed you made 6 months ago now you have to lie in it.  I have no interest in giving your game a second chance just as I'm sure you have no interest in refunding my money.  If you didn't want the reviews to go the way they did you should have pushed back release.  Hindsight is 20/20 and mistakes can be forgiven but trying to post on negative reviews telling the people you've ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off (because they paid full price for your crud game) to revisit it in the hopes they'll edit their reviews is beyond rude.  I payed for your damn game and tried to play it

REVIEW outdated, big REDUX Update is out, but I won't test it, so just ignore this review, it's for Version 1.0.



Was looking forward to this game, now I am unfortunately quite disappointed.
While the idea is great and the setting is very intriguing, the mechanics are lackluster.
Combat is turnbased, similar to Banner Saga (whose engine this game uses) but it is poorly executed
-You only have two turns
-there is not much variety (shooting, running, special abilities from your crawler)
-enemies seem to have the upper hand always, killing your team mates often with just one hit (the sniper seems to be useless, because his range is not far enough to stay out of the enemies firing range and he has only 2 hitpoints)
-game feels like a mobile port, with big buttons, a practically nonexisting Options menu and a odd feeling way to reach different screens
-the learning curve is unfair, unlike in other roguelikes (e.g. FTL, Banner Saga)
-art style in battle is not that pretty

TL;DR
+incredible setting
+good ideas
-lackluster battle mechanics
-mobile-ish

VERDICT: Try it, if you do not like it, refund it. I didn't like it, but the game deserves a chance.

reviewText:
I kickstarted this with a decent enough expectation... liking turn based games and all... but soon after playing it... I was already preparing to pan the game top to bottom. I really tried to force myself to finish ONE run of the campaign, squeezing out any fun that could be found for my wasted pledge funds, but simply couldn't because it's too frustrating. TL DR=don't buy this. Not recommended at all. If you want more details why I consider this game to be in every way a complete flop, read on...

Right from the start, the game falls flat. It's another one of these games with no volume sliders and only 1 resolution. Really? In 2015? It comes off as a cheap flash game. Sound, on or off. Music, on or off. Resolution, full or box, which is 1 tiny box at about 1024x800p, a standard resolution... 10-15 or so years ago. Is this the best they could do? Is this the top resolution they use themselves? For 20$ in 2015 I think our standard these days is a bit higher, no? I do like the graphics and art style for the game, there is that. It's quite comparable to Borderlands, which is probably where they got it all... but that's pretty much the only + I'll be giving the game here. But even this comes up short because the in game combat models are highly repetitive and do not in any way represent character models, except 1 for male, and 1 for female. If every character on the field was unique to match up with their character screen models, that would have helped.

So you start playing... and the real frustration begins. Just using the menus and controls is annoying as the developers don't seem to have ever played other video games before. I can't just click to add or remove crew from my squad, no no, I have to click and drag each time to do either of these. I also can't right click to go back a screen, which is a simple concept of convenience. They instead want you to select the icons every time to go forward or back. I'm not new to video games, you know. Lords of the Realm 2 is a more convenient game than this one in terms of menus... and it's 20 years old. You left click something to go forward a screen, and can right click to go back. Not complicated. This kind of crap reminds me of Rogue Legacy, another game crippled by terrible menu controls, but at least that was otherwise a good game itself. Then there's this game's combat, where you left click to move the screen around, right click to move a character, but then left click to shoot. I mean, what the hell? Why not just left click to move the camera or select units, then right click for both of the other options??? It's so confusing the way they've done it, and I can't imagine why they would have done it this way. You even get characters or their health bars blocking each other or other units on the screen, making selections more difficult. Sometimes a character can't move somewhere you want at all, when nothing is actually blocking the squares, which is absurd. I know I'm complaining about small things, but they do bother me, and they're worth mentioning in my book.

More small things I'll complain about before getting to the real deal breakers are the cheering audiences in every fight and the announcer. Who are these people? Are they following my dozer around? When I fight, where is this cheering audience coming from? Who is this announcer guy yelling out worthless crap? This isn't a sports event. You know what's really immersive in a barren desert? Cheering crowds and a derp sports announcer. Why can't I turn these offf, at least? No no, they're shared with the sound effects option for the whole game. Stupid, pointless, and unable to turn off without muting the whole game.

Getting past the small things finally; what really" kills this for me is the terrible combat system
