reviewText:
I really wanted to like Skyshine's Bedlam......

I saw glimpses of greatness that put it up there for me potential wise with FTL, but i just can't give it a possitive score at the moment with some of the glaring issues the game has. The combat(at the moment) while solid feels completly unbalanced even at low bedlam levels. The AI completly outmatches me because i'm lacking some pretty basic feedback in the interface that should be there, stuff like an actual grid option on the floor to plan movements better and easier to see/understand range markers.

I get that the theme of the game is that your suppost to have the odds stacked against you as you progress (i play a lot of XCOM so nothing new there) but even with veterans and max level guys the combat balancing feels horriffic in certain fights even with equalizers avalible to you. Plus theres no real padded out progression on your soldiers other than flat stat increases. Normally i wouldnt have a problem with this but whats the point in having all those cool backstories and lore for your guys if all they get on a level up is a sole re-skin job and some +1's. The Dozer isn't much better with flat percentage upgrades and a few (but admititedly intresting) unique abilities per vehicle.

Despite all of that i do have some hope for the game, we are only 6-7 hours into open release, im a picky *ss lol and most of what i see wrong with it can be patched out or changed, there is a solid game under the hood somwhere here and with some luck the devs will change some things for the better.

Pros:
- Lovely art style and setting
- Interesting characters even with individual backstories
- Solid turn based combat

Cons:
-The combat (at the moment) feels completly broken and unrewarding
- RNG is huge (yes i know its a rogue-like but 2 HP sharpshooters getting RNG'ed on spawn 4-6 tiles from the enemy every fight is just stupid)
-Any lack of meaningfull upgrades on the Dozers or soldiers

reviewText:
There's a lot here to enjoy, as well as a lot to dislike...heavily.   I'll try to elaborate on what I personally like/dislike.  Others' experiences may vary.



The Good:

-The game conveys the suspense they were trying to achieve pretty well.  Through the fear of losing your squad members, or outright losing your game (encounters)

-The combat is pretty fun, for the most part.  It's unforgiving, but once you get the hang of how to set yourself up to attack and make them waste a turn moving into position, you'll fare better and better.  But you're gonna be heavily outnumbered later on, and your ranked-up members will still get rekt pretty quickly (esp in boss battles) so you have to be really tactical

-There are a lot of bosses/special characters you can defeat/recruit to your side.  They are usually pretty strong, but definitely can still be killed if you're not careful.

-The graphic style is pleasing and the controls are simple.  the turn-based aspect is definitely fun (only two actions per turn).

-The narrative is fun and different.  There are a lot of random encounters, some good, some bad.



The Neutral:

-Combat is hit-and-miss.  It feels very savage.  The attacks are pretty awesome and the sounds convey impact.  The squad members all have attack ranges which is nice, but the way they implement ranged attacks is kinda frustrating.  The gunslinger can attack medium-long ranges (about 8-10 tiles) but only at that range.  any closer and you can't attack.  but at least he can reposition to attack on most turns if necessary.  The sniper can hit about 10-11 tiles away but can only move 2.  Which is very very annoying since you're rarely within the correct range to attack, unless you're specifically trying to use him.  I feel his range should be longer, like 10-14 tiles.  Makes him more useful without having to be EXACTLY at the correct range or get too close (10 tiles is WAY too close when you have 2 health).



The BAD

-The game is extremely unforgiving.  Which, I know, was their intent.  But it's really annoying when you have a sniper that you've fed enemies, in order to get him ranked up, and the enemy sniper moves just into position and wastes him.  (the highest health a sniper can get is 5, and the rookiest snipers do 5 dmg, so a rookie can one-shot your all-star, 25+ kill, sniper.   This can happen with every one of your squad members.  Ranking them up is quite tedious.  You're doing well if you can get the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ rookies to actually kill 3 enemies and not die.  Only to have them get blasted later.  I understand that this is their intent, but it's not fun (to me).

-The easiest difficulty is pretty pointless.  It's just as unforgiving and has the downside of no achievement awards.

-The pacing is pretty poor.  It's fun and challenging at the start, but ramps up to ridiculous levels really fast.  You're guaranteed to lose squad members, which is fine, but I have yet to be able to recruit ANYONE that's not a boss to my side.  The only time I've gotten more players to my side is when I reached a certain point (no spoilers), and even then it was only a handful.

-Random encounters usually end one of two ways.  Usually you get attacked or you find nothing of interest and leave.  There are, of course, several outcomes, but they seem so rare to actually have happen.  The ONLY reason I explored everything was to find another ship to use.  Other than that, you're just risking losing squad members due to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ battle-RNG only for piddly scraps.  Waste of time and possibilites.  Could've been awesome.


Final Note:

I was really on the fence about this game.  I pre-ordered it because the gameplay looked awesome.  I was so excited to play it.   The combat is really fun.  Turns out that the combat is not as often as I'd have liked (I wish there was a combat-focused mode like in Blood-Bowl).  I cannot just recruit new fighters like xcom can.  So you're going from one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ battle to the next just slowly losing more and more members till you're down to nobody left for when the game really gets hard (won't spoil it).  I really wanted to like this game.  Hopefully it will be improved, but I'm not holding my breath


UPDATE:  After putting a few more hours into the game, in an attempt to force myself to figure it out a little better.

-Recruiting new non-bosses IS possible, but very rare.
-Frontliners are the best class, everyone else is just inferior for several reasons (ranged classes have low mobility and weird range requirements, and shotgunners have same range as frontliners, but less mobility, plus knockback usually ends up making consecutive attacks impossible). Frontliners have great mobility, good scaling damage, the most health.  i was killing 13+ enemy battles with just two frontliners after a while

reviewText:
I really wish there were more options than just thumbs up or thumbs down. For me, this game exists right at the border.

It's a 5/10 game as it is right now.

I have the feeling that the game will get a lot better as the devs respond to feedback and flesh the game out. I may end up revising this review.

But, for right now, it only feels like half a game. The main issue is that there simply isn't that much to do. You drive around the desert on rails, random stuff happens, you fight. Problem is, the fighting system isn't all that robust. I understand that the devs are currently reconsidering the two turn activation system, and I think they should. As someone who has played numerous tabletop wargames over 25 years, this system makes no sense to me. It's both needlessly complex and too simplistic at the same time. There are lots of better ways to achieve what I think the devs were going for with it.

I hate to say it, but, as the game is currently, it's basically Oregon Trail with really awesome art design and lore. But it's got potential to become something great - the art design is quirky and beautiful, and the world they've created is very rich. Make the combat a little more robust, add some playable races, and make Bedlam more of a sandbox and this game will be great. Until then, I hate to do it, but I've got to give it a thumbs down.

reviewText:
I’m really, really disappointed. The game was too promising to fail, but it failed. Maybe it would be ok, if the game was it alpha or even early access state. But NO, this is an official release!

The main issue is broken mechanics. Developers say that this is “roguelike design”, but it is not. It’s just total random. You are so limited of actions that nothing depends of your skill. You can lose the combat before it starts, just because of unlucky random unit deployment. In addition to broken mechanics, you should fight the poor balance. There are 4 classes, but at least 2 of them are useless. Leveling up your specific units is also useless:  they are all the same, will die randomly and you can do nothing with this.

Do not buy this game, if you are not willing to participate in beta test. At least in Sep 2015. Right now, this game is in early beta state (like Rome Total War 2 release). There is so much to work with: bugs, combat mechanic, balance, resource management and etc, that I really doubt, that this game will be ever finished. So, DO NOT BUT THIS GAME RIGHT NOW. You may continue to play FTL instead.

I'd be quite impressed if this were an early access game, but it's not, and I can't generally recommend it in its current state unless $20 is cheap to you and you are OK playing a game that is deeply flawed and not worth playing through more than once or twice (which takes only a few hours). If $20 is free to you and you lke FTL type games I would pick this up because it is fun for a few hours even if the experience will probably leave you a bit annoyed by the numerous weak design decisions. Hopefully the game will undergo substantial changes and I could easily imagine this game becoming a real gem but there is substantial work between here and there.

My play experience (note I include some spoilers):

-First run lost to the boss because he is basically cheesy and just a test of how much power you have stockpiled and I hadn't stockpiled hardly any power

-Second run I won, but just barely and the final fight I got through with one soldier left and only won due to egregious AI mistakes. I started the ascension run" with about 300 power

-Third run I also won

reviewText:
I want to give it a thumb up but when I find myself wanting to turn it off and play other management style rouge-like it would be a lie to do so...

The game does seem to have potential but it fails to deliver in many areas...

Lazy art. For the most part player end up controlling just a handful of characters and when the art of those characters is same body with different heads slapped into it ala dress-up game those characters dont feel like individuals that you can get attached to.

Not random enough for it to be a rouge-like. All pathways seem to be the same, the only random factor that you will find is the faction type slapped on to a map territory. All side missions layout follows the same un-varying formula of 4 points of interest per route stage. This just makes a game a tad too predictable to be of any actual interest and you end up ignoring most (if not all) of those pois most of the time.(what a waste)

Lazy Random events. Those are made in the form of multiple choice with a bit of writting slapped on top of it. The writting itself is bland and too repetitive for the starters (it follows the same template too closely.. no literaly value in those at all). And once you encounter an event you memorize it and never make a bad choice in the playthroughs which make those boring and not up to par with a good rouge-like desing.

Combat, while is using The Banner Saga engine, falls heavily short. Characters don't have any special abilities and because of the damage to hp ratio in this game is insane battles feel like I am forced to have my characters get killed no matter what and no ammount of being smart at tactical strategies can help you avoid that. You quickly learn that you HAVE to exploit game ai weaknesess to minize a chance of loosing people and that a HUGE design flaw.

Averal, compared to similar rouge-like games, Bedlam falls short of content, variation and atmosphere and thats a shame because I really want this game to be good :(

reviewText: I really wish I could recommend this game but I just can’t. My expectations for this game were fairly hi which is suppose is my own fault. I really thought this would be something like an FTl fallout hybrid. Sadly this game is just bedlam. I’ll start with the combat. The combat is just bad plain and simple. At a glance at the map there are a number of unique zones with different factions and interactions. Upon closer examination every zone is pretty much exactly the same with enemies being graphically different and that’s it and the events themselves are all pretty much the same regardless of the zone you are in. This game had a lot of potential it just failed to deliver combat was bad the events were boring really the only thing this game delivered on was a cool art style.

reviewText:
== Update for Redux ==

This update is amazing. Each squad member having their own set of actions is exactly what I thought it would be from the beginning and I love it. Arcade and Campaign modes are both great ways to replay the game with different pacing. The reworked health and damage is nice since you don't have to worry so much about your units getting one-shot. Being able to finally choose your starting crews and factions is great. This feels like the game that should have been released from the start.

I can't give the devs enough credit for their response to player feedback. They've been awesome.

== Update 02-11 for Patch 2.0 ==

Bleh. I still don't like combat, and now you're forced to waste you're already limited actions per turn to farm resources on the battle grid because of the loss of the resource rewards after combat. I hate that change. Should I attack the enemy in the middle of combat or should I run to some corner of the battlefield to collect some steaks? It's completely anti-fun to me to do that.

Thumbs back down.

== Update 24-09 for Patch 1.5 ==

Patch 1.5 is a big improvement for perceived difficulty caused by RNG. Board placement is fair, though I'm not sure if completely eliminating ambush maps was necessary. It was bad getting them 3-4 times in a row, but now it doesn't seem to ever happen. Achievements seem to work now (aside from the high score achievements not also counting for the score achievements below it) and now you can actually complete the game after you kill King Viscera's 4th form.

The cover change is great since now you can rely on it when planning your two moves. It seems to be a really harsh penalty to Gunslingers though since after rounding their damage becomes 1. You can pretty much ignore enemy gunslingers in cover now. Frontliners and Trenchers can ignore cover at point blank and Deadeyes at rookie still do at least 2 damage. I never see my Gunslingers retaliate either; they might need some kind of buff.

I'm so far not really liking the leveling changes. It was already grindy to me before and now it seems more so. Elite units take 8 kills to level now instead of 5, which wasn't in patch notes. With reduced numbers of enemies and the elimination of the mandatory fight, there is less kills to get before you get to the first elite. A lot of times I get to the first elite without any veterans now, which makes that fight pretty rough. Badlam difficulty is slight easier to level than Normal now because there are slightly more enemies - which seems backward. Recruiting new non-elite units still feels like a waste; like I want to bring some rookie unit into a Severe/Bedlam threat level combat. With the normal unit leveling change, it seems like more level grinding now to fight KV.

The loss of the x2 Power bonus kind of sucks. Power seems much harder to get now and reliant on risking units to collect the map powerups. I'm not sure how I feel about it yet, but KV fights still seem reliant on hording a lot of Power before Aztec City (based on continuing the unfinished game I had pre-1.5 waiting for the end game bug to be fixed). This combined with the leveling change maintains the POI grind you have to do before Aztec City. I'm not sure if that fits with the fast-paced rush to AC that the developers seem to want. I feel like leveling should be either quicker or easier to spread among units (instead of funneling kills into a few units). Farming every POI you can to gather Power shouldn't feel necessary either. KV still has a crap-ton of HP, so fighting him still requires equalizer spamming and hoping that you find the good ones by then.

Overall, I really like this patch. I think it just needs a little more tweaking to the pacing (i.e. grinding), maybe slight balance tweaks to KV (which would decrease grinding and improve pacing), and some improvement to the random events to make the decisions you make seem more impactful. Even though I'm still not much of a fan of the 2AP system, I'd be more inclined to recommend the game to people who like roguelikes and chess so I'm flipping my thumbs down to a thumbs up. Developer response to feedback has been awesome; they deserve a lot of credit.

The Good:
* Post-apocalyptic setting like Wasteland/Fallout/Mad Max always makes my nipples hard.
* Graphics and animation. Nothing is more satisfying than melting people with Chunderok's barf attack, blasting the flesh from their skeleton with a Gunslinger, or kicking someone in the nuts and elbow dropping them as they double over.
* Losing due to randomness is much less decreased, and more likely your own fault now.
* Turn-based combat (with a caveat below).
* Developer response to feedback and patching.
* Seeing my name in big gold letters in the credits.

The Bad:
* 2 actions per turn isn't my cup of tea and not generally well-received by players. It resembles chess and I don't like chess. If you do, this isn't really a bad point.
* Random event decisions don't really matter much. Some events have no impact at all except for wasting your resources to get there.
* Leveling and farming Power Cells is tedious, despite the intent for a fast-paced game.

The Ugly:
* My pants after I rage-sh!t myself because I made a mistake that kills one of my Elites or high level Frontliners.

== Update 18-09 ==

Recent patches made the Blitz much less catastrophic, so it's not as punishing anymore. I still wish it was a usable mechanic for players and not just CPU. The limited actions still makes it seem like chess to me (I hate chess). Patches brought much improvement though.

I'd say if you like roguelikes and chess, this is right up your alley. If there was a rating between yes" and "no" I'd upgrade to that
date: simply because devs are so responsive to tuning yet not giving in to lowering difficulty. I was always fine with the difficulty; it was just the random elements that crush you were too annoying. I feel like the game could've used more time in Early Access for tuning
recommended: when people may be less critical of flaws. Games like this are hard to evaluate in the 2 hour limit that Steam gives refunds

so that first impression for a final product probably brought a lot of negative response.

reviewText:
The game was tagged as an RPG in the store when I bought it, so that was a disappointment.  The tag isn't there now.  For what is now being advertised, I think that the game plays well enough.  Keep in mind that it IS NOT an RPG at all.

With the last few patches, battles are more enjoyable.

While the game looks like an in depth Mad Max style RPG/CTS almalgamation, it's not.  It's a chess game with a resource management minigame and a map encounter minigame.

Your soldiers are underpowered for being understaffed.  You get only a max of 4 to use each battle.  One dies?  That sucks buttocks.  Better hope that doesn't happen too often.  Maybe you'll get another one through a random encounter.  Maybe your soldiers will die too much because you are facing 12 enemies in a battle, and you just got pwned in 5 battles just like that.  And while you are trying to maneuver your soldiers so that the enemy can't either double team one of your soldiers and kill them in one turn or have an opportunity to first: walk up and then secondly: horribly murder your soldiers, you are also expected to gather resource pick ups on the battlefield to ensure your dozer" vehicle can continue the trip to the mythical Aztec City. reviewText:
UPDATE JANUARY 2016:
Bedlam got a rockier start than I and many other gamers could enjoy. The difficulty was too high and player agency too low. This has been adressed, and the game is now playably challenging, and even quite entertaining. It's still not a walk in the park, but if you like FTL-style repeatable roguelikes, Bedlam has become a title worth your consideration.

REVIEW AT RELEASE:
This game as it stands in late September 2015 isn't fun. It's just punishing.
I suppose some people might find enjoyment in constantly losing, but this is not a game for someone who just wants to shoot up some mutants for an hour a day. If you enjoy difficulty for difficulty's sake, go ahead. If you were looking for something in the vein of FTL or XCOM with a Fallout flavor, you may want to look elsewhere.

reviewText: The setting, art, classes, enemy types etc. are all well done.  The problems come with the story and battle mechanics.  As many reviews have mentioned, none of the choices feel like they have any actual weight (and after many playthroughs I'm pretty sure they don't).  You accept the battles, you accept the new members, you say no to shady cloak-wearing dudes (most of the time).  It doesn't feel interesting and is not at all effected by your crew, dozer type, etc.\n\nThe biggest problem of all is combat, holy ♥♥♥♥ the combat.  I'm all for challenging, but c'mon.  Two moves worked in Banner Saga, why can't it work here?  Likely because you're being pulled in too many directions.  You need those resources?  Well then your team is going to lose a few members.  Want to kill off the enemy?  You might survive, but no resources for you.  And if you try to go for resources, you'll immediately be put on a clock in the form of the Blitzometer."  In my opinion this should be done away with entirely.
